questions.text: An elderly patient diagnosed with ischemic heart disease was prescribed beta-blockers, but despite their use, his symptoms persisted. He was then started on ivabradine. By what mechanism does this drug alleviate the symptoms of angina?
questions.solution:
Ivabradine decreases the automaticity in the sinoatrial node and thus reduces the heart rate. This reduction in the heart rate decreases the myocardial oxygen demand.

The oxygen requirement of the heart mainly depends on the work done by the heart. This work mainly depends on cardiac output and peripheral resistance. An increase in these parameters will increase the oxygen requirement of the heart.

Important determinants of cardiac output are:

Stroke volume- It is the amount of blood pumped out of the heart during each heartbeat. This stroke volume increases whenever, there is increased venous return to the heart, increased end-diastolic volume (preload), and increased contractility. Contractility further depends on the initial length of the cardiac muscle fiber and the autonomic innervation.

Heart rate- Increased heart rate increases the cardiac output which in turn increases the oxygen requirement. Heart rate is controlled primarily by the autonomic nerves, with sympathetic stimulation increasing the rate and parasympathetic stimulation decreasing the rate.

Afterload- The tension at which the load is lifted is called afterload. As the afterload increases, the heart has to work more in order to pump blood to the organs. This in turn results in increased oxygen requirement. It is dependent on the peripheral resistance. 

Drugs used in the management of angina either decrease the work done by the heart or increases the blood flow to the heart.

  • Nitrates- They increase the cGMP and cause venodilation. It mainly results in an increase in venous capacitance and a decrease in the ventricular preload. They might also increase coronary flow in some areas and in variant anginas.
  • Calcium channel blockers- Blocking the calcium channels leads to the relaxation of vascular smooth muscles and decreased impulses in the conduction system. This leads to decreased peripheral resistance, decreased blood pressure, decreased contractility, decreased heart rate, and decreased oxygen requirement of the heart.
  • Beta-blockers- They decrease the oxygen requirement by decreasing the heart rate, blood pressure, and contractility. Some drugs like carvedilol and nebivolol also cause vasodilation.

Newer antianginal drugs

  • Ranolazine- It inhibits the late sodium current and reduces the intracellular calcium concentration. It reduces diastolic tension, cardiac contractility, and work.
  • Trimetazidine- inhibits the fatty acid oxidation in the myocardium. It decreases the oxygen requirement of the heart.
  • Ivabradine- decreases the heart rate and decreases oxygen requirement.
  • Fasudil- It is a Rho kinase inhibitor. It is useful in coronary vasospasm.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - Dilates veins > arteries. Reduces preload.
  • Calcium channel blockers - Blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - Amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - Verapamil, Diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - Decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs 
    • Ranolazine - Late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - Inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - Rho-kinase inhibitor

The  restriction enzyme acts at a specific palindromic sequence, GATATC- CTATAG as mentioned in option b, when RFLP is used in-order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU.

RFLP is a restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis technique that involves cutting a particular region of DNA with known variability, with restriction enzymes, then separating the DNA fragments by agarose gel electrophoresis and determining the number of fragments and relative sizes. 

Cleavage of a sample of DNA with a restriction enzyme produces a characteristic set of smaller DNA fragments. Deviations in the normal product pattern, produce RFLPs that occur if a mutation renders a restriction site unrecognizable and alternatively, generates a new recognition site. 

This is used clinically for prenatal detection of genetic disorders with mutations like sickle cell disease, thalassemias, phenylketonuria in infants, and Huntington's disease. They can also be used to trace the source of the DNA sample to a particular individual.

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of arthralgia, abdominal pain, palpable purpura, and past history of upper respiratory tract infection suggests Henoch Schonlein's purpura (HSP). Glucocorticoids are used to treat HSP.

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), also known as IgA vasculitis, is a common small vessel vasculitis in childhood. It is a type III hypersensitivity reaction characterized by the deposition of IgA in the small vessels of the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidney, resulting in vasculitis.

The exact etiology of HSP remains unknown. But, it usually occurs following an upper respiratory tract infection caused by group A Streptococcus, Staphylococcus aureus, Mycoplasma, and Adenovirus.

Children usually present with the following features:

  • Palpable purpura is symmetric and occurs in the lower extremities, extensor aspect of the upper limbs, and buttocks.
  • Arthralgia and arthritis- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints.
  • Gastrointestinal manifestations like abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and intussusception.
  • About 30% of the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, presenting as microscopic hematuria, hypertension, and progressive glomerulonephritis.

Glucocorticoids such as prednisolone are used for the treatment of gastrointestinal manifestations in HSP. Nephritis due to IgA vasculitis should be treated with immunosuppressants like prednisolone and azathioprine.

 The image given below shows palpable purpura in the lower limbs seen in HSP.

The criteria for diagnosis of childhood HSP are:

Palpable purpura with at least one of the following-

  • Diffuse abdominal pain
  • Any biopsy showing predominant IgA deposition
  • Arthritis or arthralgia
  • Renal involvement (proteinuria >3 g/24 hr), hematuria, or red cell casts

Lab findings seen in HSP are nonspecific and include leukocytosis, mild anemia, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). The platelet count is normal in HSP. A skin biopsy specimen can be useful in confirming leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition by immunofluorescence.

The image given below shows IgA and C3 deposition in vessels seen on immunofluorescence of skin biopsy in HSP.

Other options:

Immunosuppressants like azathioprine, methotrexate, and cyclosporine are used in a variety of rheumatologic disorders like vasculitis, arthritis, inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, autoimmune hepatitis, and lupus nephritis.

questions.text: The thoracic duct begins in the abdomen at the T12 vertebral level as the continuation of cisterna chyli. Which of the following structures is not drained by it?
questions.solution:
Right upper part of the body is not drained by the thoracic duct. The rest of the body drains into the thoracic duct.

The thoracic duct begins in the abdomen at the T-12 vertebral level as the continuation of cisterna chyli.

  • It is usually beaded due to its numerous valves.
  • It drains the body below the diaphragm (lower limbs, pelvis, abdomen) and the left half of the body above the diaphragm (thorax, upper limb, head, and neck).
  • The thoracic duct passes through the aortic hiatus in the diaphragm and ascends through the posterior mediastinum between the aorta and the azygous vein.
  • At the T-5 level, it deviates to the left side and ascends to pass the thoracic inlet.

Tributaries of the thoracic duct:

  • Bilateral (right and left) descending thoracic lymph trunks which convey lymph from lower intercostal spaces (6–11).
  • Left upper intercostal lymph trunks, which convey lymph from the upper intercostal spaces (1-5).
  • Mediastinal lymph trunks
  • Left subclavian lymph trunk
  • Left jugular lymph trunk
  • Left bronchomediastinal lymph trunk

questions.text: A cyanotic newborn is suspected of having congenital heart disease. He has an increased left ventricular impulse and a holosystolic murmur along the left sternal border. ECG shows left axis deviation and left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of clinical cyanosis in combination with left-axis deviation (LAD) and left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) noted on the electrocardiogram are suggestive of tricuspid atresia.

Other points in favor:

  • Increased left ventricular impulse (in contrast to most other causes of cyanotic heart disease, in which an increased right ventricular impulse).
  • Holosystolic murmurs are audible along the left sternal border (due to associated ventricular septal defect).

Tricuspid atresia is the congenital absence of the tricuspid valve. So, blood cannot flow directly from the right atrium to the right ventricle, and the following associated defects are necessary for survival:

  • Patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect: for the flow of blood from the right atrium to the left atrium
  • Ventricular septal defect: for the flow of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle
  • There is a hypoplastic right ventricle.

Other options:

Option B and D: Truncus arteriosus and tetralogy of Fallot and - The ECG demonstrates right axis deviation (RAD) and evidence of RVH.

Option A: Transposition of great arteries- ECG is usually normal, showing the neonatal right-sided dominant pattern.

questions.text: A patient presented with corneal opacities and renal failure. On investigation, the enzyme lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase was found to be completely deficient. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the investigation showing complete deficiency of the enzyme lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) points to the diagnosis of Norum's disease.

Familial lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase deficiency (FLD), also called Norum disease occurs when the deficiency of LCAT is complete. It is a rare genetic disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. Here, the reverse cholesterol transport is affected leading to decreased circulating HDL cholesterol. Clinical features are dense corneal opacity and renal failure.

Fish-eye disease (FED) is due to a partial deficiency in LCAT activity.

Other options:

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged yellow-orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. Clinical features of Tangier disease include hyperplastic yellow-orange tonsils, hepatosplenomegaly, and peripheral neuropathy, which may be either relapsing-remitting or chronic progressive in nature

Option C: Abetalipoproteinemia is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a defect in the MTTP gene causing defective microsomal triglyceride protein. Here, loading apolipoprotein B with lipids is defective. Hence, few very low-density-lipoproteins (VLDLs) or chylomicrons are formed, leading to the accumulation of triacylglycerols in the liver and intestine.

Option D: Acid lipase enzyme deficiency can lead to Wolman's disease which is a lysosomal storage disease. The pathognomic feature of this condition is adrenal calcification. Infants generally present with failure to thrive, abdominal distention, vomiting, steatorrhea, and hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the structure shown in the given image not seen?
questions.solution:
The above image shows psammoma bodies. They are found in all of the above mentioned conditions except in schwannoma.

Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellated structures formed as a product of dystrophic calcification. They are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by infarction and calcification of papillae tips. 

Conditions associated with psammoma bodies include-

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma
  • Meningiomas.

Verocay bodies are found in schwannomas. Verocay bodies are spindle cells that are arranged to form central “nuclear-free zones” ramified by palisading nuclei. Antoni A area is a dense eosinophilic area containing spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei lying in the palisading pattern. The resulting structures with central nuclear-free zones ratified by the palisading of nuclei are termed Verocay bodies.  The loose hypocellular Antoni B area contains spindle cells spread apart by the myxoid extracellular matrix.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine?
questions.solution:
VIP is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine.

Cholinergic neurons passing in anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus.

Cholinergic neurons passing in retrograde direction produce substance P (Option c) and acetylcholine (Option b) which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

 

 

In achalasia cardia there is decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient on oral contraceptives presented with abdominal pain and increasing abdominal girth for the past five days. Physical examination revealed hepatomegaly and ascites. A liver biopsy showed severe centrilobular congestion and necrosis and organized thrombi in the major hepatic veins. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and histopathological findings are suggestive of hepatic vein thrombosis or Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Obstruction of the major hepatic veins due to thrombosis leads to a condition known as Budd-Chiari syndrome. It presents with a triad of abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and ascites. The damage to the hepatic tissue is a result of increased intrahepatic blood pressure. It principally affects young women with an underlying hypercoagulable state such as deficiency of protein C, S, or anti-thrombin. Oral contraceptive intake increases the risk of hepatic vein thrombosis. Hepatic vein thrombosis is also associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms like polycythemia vera, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Grossly the liver is swollen, red-purple in color and has a tense capsule. Microscopically, there may be areas of hemorrhage alternating with areas of preserved parenchyma. Centrilobular congestion and necrosis is seen. The major hepatic veins contain thrombi and they may get organized into the wall of the vessel.

Other options:

Option B: Metastatic liver disease - It typically presents with multiple liver lesions and is not associated with centrilobular congestion, organized thrombi in the major hepatic veins, or the clinical picture described in the scenario. 

Option C: Primary biliary cholangitis, previously called primary biliary cirrhosis, is an autoimmune disease associated with inflammatory destruction of small- and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It usually presents with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. 

Option D: Secondary biliary cirrhosis refers to inflammation, fibrosis, and scarring, secondary to chronic obstruction of the extrahepatic bile ducts.

questions.text: A drug having a half-life of 8 hours is administered orally thrice daily. How much time will be taken for the plasma concentration to reach a steady state?
questions.solution:
The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives. As the half-life of the given drug is 8 hours, so it will take 32-40 hours to reach a steady state. Hence, 36 hours will be the most appropriate answer.

Steady-state: The amount of drug administered is equal to the amount of drug eliminated within one dosing interval resulting in a plateau or constant drug plasma concentration, with the plasma concentration fluctuating between a minimum and maximum.

The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives.

Drugs with a shorter half-life reach a steady state rapidly, whereas drugs with longer half-life take days to weeks to attain a steady state.

Steady-state concentration (Css) = F x Dosing rate/ CL

  • where dosing rate is the dose per time interval and is dose/T
  • F is the fractional bioavailability, CL is clearance.

questions.text:
The image of PAH excretion is depicted below. Match the labellings.

PAH - Para Amino Hippuric acid

Tm - Transport maximum

choices.text: a. Filtered, b. Excreted, c. Tm, d. Secreted
a. Filtered, b. Secreted, c. Tm, d. Excreted
a. Secreted, b. Filtered, c. Tm, d. Excreted
a. Excreted, b. Filtered, c. Tm, d. Secreted

questions.solution:
The labellings depticed are a - Filtered, b - Secreted, c -Tm (Transport maximum) and d - Excreted.

Filtered load = GFR x Plasma concentration. The filtered load of PAH increases linearly as the unbound concentration of PAH increases.

Secretion - At low concentrations of PAH, many carriers are available and secretion increases linearly as the plasma concentration increases. When the PAH concentration increases to a level where the carriers are saturated, Tm is reached. After this point, no matter how much the PAH concentration increases, there can be no further increase in the secretion rate.

Excretion - For a secreted substance such as PAH, excretion is the sum of filtration and secretion. At low PAH concentrations (below Tm), excretion increases steeply with increases in plasma PAH concentration because both filtration and secretion are increasing. At PAH concentrations above Tm, excretion increases less steeply (and parallels the curve for filtration) because only the filtration component increases as concentration increases; secretion is already saturated.

questions.text: Obstruction at the location labeled A in the image below would lead to the dilation of all the following cerebral ventricles or structures except:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius, which connects the third ventricle with the fourth ventricle.

Blockage of the CSF flow, at the aqueduct would result in the distension of all the spaces proximal to it, which includes the third ventricle, interventricular foramen, and the lateral ventricles. Thus the fourth ventricle, which receives the CSF from the cerebral aqueduct does not get distended when the aqueduct is blocked.

The ventricular system is derived from the inner lumen of the developing neural tube. Lining the ventricles is the choroid plexus, consisting of modified ependymal cells responsible for producing the CSF. From the lateral ventricles, CSF flows through the interventricular foramen of Monro to the third ventricle. The third ventricle communicates with the fourth ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius, which courses through the midbrain. Surrounded by the pons and medulla anteriorly and the cerebellum posteriorly, the fourth ventricle sends CSF out of the ventricular system and into the subarachnoid space via the lateral foramina of Luschka and midline foramen of Magendie.

questions.text: A young HIV-positive patient presents with complaints of fever and neck stiffness. The patient's cerebrospinal fluid sample when stained with India ink reveals the following finding. The organism responsible for this infection is transmitted by which of the following methods?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cryptococcosis which is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. This organism is usually transmitted through inhalation but occasionally also through skin and mucosa.

Cryptococcus neoformans is a round/ovoid budding cell with a prominent polysaccharide capsule. This capsule can be visualized with the assistance of the India ink stain.

Cryptococcal meningitis and meningoencephalitis are opportunistic infections seen in patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). Patients present with symptoms such as fever/headache. Patients are treated with a combination of Amphotericin with flucytosine.

Other options:

Option A: Diseases such as Lyme disease and Q fever are transmitted by the bite of ixodid ticks.

Option B: Cat scratch disease is caused by Bartonella henselae. It presents as a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch.

Option D: Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri is acquired by swimming in freshwater rivers or ponds.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has been recently approved for the radical cure of  Plasmodium vivax malaria?
questions.solution:
Tafenoquine has been recently approved for the radical cure of plasmodium vivax malaria. It is used for the prevention of relapse of Plasmodium vivax malaria in patients who are 16 years or older. It is not indicated in acute infection.

Halofantrine is an orally administered blood schizontocide which is active against both chloroquine sensitive and resistant plasmodia. It is not a recently approved drug and it has serious side effects most commonly cardiotoxicity and QT prolongation, so it is usually not used unless in severe cases of malaria. (option a)

Ivacaftor is a cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) potentiator, that is used for the treatment of cystic fibrosis (CF) in patients age 2 years and older. (Option C)

Ibalizumab is a CD4 directed HIV-1 inhibitor. It is used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant HIV infection. (Option D)

questions.text: Choose the correct option regarding the following graph.

choices.text: Point C represents the value which occurs with greatest frequency
Here the mode is greater than the mean
It is a positively skewed distribution
Point B represents the mean of the distribution

questions.solution:
This is an example of a left-skewed or negatively skewed distribution, and shows the relation between mean, median and mode as Mode>median > mean.

The relationship among the three measures of central tendency depends on the shape of the distribution. All three measures are identical in an unimodal symmetrical distribution (such as the normal distribution), so Mean=Median =Mode. In a skewed distribution, the three variables of central tendency are not equal.

In a positively skewed/ right-skewed distribution, the mode is simply the most frequently occurring score (the highest point on the curve); the mean is pulled up by the influence of a relatively small number of very high scores; and the median lies between the two, dividing the distribution into two equal areas under the curve. On the curve mean > median > mode.

Conversely, in a negatively skewed/ left-skewed distribution, the mode is again the most frequently occurring score (the highest point on the curve); the mean is pulled down by the influence of a relatively small number of very low scores; and the median lies between the two. On the curve, we find mean < median < mode.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (b) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (c) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (a) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: A young woman presented with a rash as shown in the image below. She also complains of recurrent oral ulcers and pain in multiple joints. Investigations revealed antibodies to double-stranded DNA. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A young woman with a butterfly-shaped malar rash, a history of recurrent oral ulcers, pain in multiple joints, and antibodies to double-stranded DNA is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

SLE is an autoimmune disorder that results in damage to multiple organs and organ systems in the body most commonly seen in women of reproductive age.  

Clinical and immunological manifestations of SLE:

  1. Skin
    • acute, subacute cutaneous manifestations (photosensitivity, malar or maculopapular rash)
    • chronic cutaneous manifestations (discoid lupus, panniculitis, lichen planus-like) 
  2. Oral or nasal ulcers
  3. Non-scarring alopecia
  4. Synovitis involving ≥2 joints
  5. Serositis (pleurisy, pericarditis)
  6. Renal: 
    • Protein/Creatinine ratio >0.5
    • RBC casts
  7. Neurologic: seizures, psychosis, myelitis, neuropathy, confusional state
  8. Hemolytic anemia
  9. Leukopenia
  10. Thrombocytopenia
  11. Immunological manifestations
    • Antinuclear antibodies >reference value (positive in >98% patients)
    • Anti-dsDNA >reference value (specific)
    • Anti-Smith antibody (specific)
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (lupus anticoagulant, false-positive rapid plasma reagin)
    • Low serum complement

To diagnose SLE, at least 4 out of 11 of the above criteria must be positive. However, if a renal biopsy is suggestive of lupus nephritis and lupus autoantibodies are positive then four criteria are not required. 

Other options: 

Option A: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory myopathy that presents with symmetrical weakness in the proximal muscles. Classical dermatological manifestations include- gottron's papules (raised erythematous rash) on the knuckles, and elbows, a shawl sign on the back, and the heliotrope rash over the eyelids (erythematous discoloration with periorbital edema). Laboratory findings include elevated creatinine kinase levels and autoantibodies like anti-Mi2.

Option B: Behcet's disease is a multisystem disorder that requires recurrent oral ulceration plus two of the following criteria for a definitive diagnosis -

  • Recurrent genital ulceration
  • Ocular lesions
  • Skin lesions 
  • Positive pathergy test

Laboratory findings are usually non-specific signs of inflammation and elevated C-reactive protein levels.

Option C: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease that results in damage to the articular cartilage. It can also have a broad range of extra-articular manifestations. questions.text:
Which of the following vector indices are related specifically to the mosquito shown in the image?
  1. Human Blood Index
  2. Biting Density
  3. Aedes aegypti index
  4. Inoculation rate
  5. Annual parasite incidence
questions.solution:
The image given is that of an Anopheles mosquito, which is the vector for malaria. Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high as shown in the image above. 

Malarial vector indices include the following:

  1. Human Blood Index
  2. Sporozoite rate
  3. Mosquito Density
  4. Man Biting Rate
  5. Inoculation Rate
  • Human Blood Index: Proportion of freshly-fed female Anopheline mosquitoes whose stomach contains human blood. It indicates the degree of anthrophilism.
  • Sporozoite rate: Percentage of female anophelines with sporozoites in their salivary glands.
  • Mosquito Density: Number of mosquitoes per man- hour-catch.
  • Man Biting Rate (Biting density): Average incidence of anopheline bites per day per person. It is determined by standardized vector catches on human bait.
  • Inoculation Rate: The man-biting rate multiplied by the infective sporozoite rate is called the inoculation rate.

All these rates are employed in the quantitative assessment of malaria and in building up a composite epidemiological picture of malaria.

Other options:

Aedes aegypti index: This is a house index and is defined as the percentage of houses and their premises, in a limited well-defined area, showing actual breeding of Aedes aegypti larvae. This index should be less than 1 percent in towns and seaports in endemic areas with yellow fever.

The annual parasite incidence is used in classifying states/UTs in the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India. The annual parasite Incidence is calculated as (Cases in one year ×1000) / Population under surveillance. It is a measure of malaria incidence.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with fever, erythematous rash, and bone pain. X-ray of the skull shows multiple lytic lesions. Skin biopsy shows prominent nuclear grooves with eosinophils as in the image below. Immunohistochemistry for S100, CD1a is also shown in the images below. What would be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathological image showing Langerhans cells with folded nuclei (image A), CD1a (image B), and positive S100 (image C), is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).

LCH occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens. The most common mutation is the BRAFV600E gain-of-function mutation.

It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions and can also infiltrate nearly every organ, like the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. 

LCH can present as the following clinical entities:

  • Multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (Letterer-Siwe disease) - mostly seen in infants
  • Unifocal and multifocal uni system Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophilic granuloma) - The combination of bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos is called the Hand-Schüller-Christian triad - mostly seen in younger children
  • Pulmonary LCH - mostly seen in adults

Clinical features include pain and swelling in the affected area. When calvarium is affected, it results in otitis media and mastoiditis. Spinal involvement results in compression fractures and neurological involvement. Vertebral involvement results in a rapid flattening of the vertebral body (vertebra plana).

Histopathologically, Langerhans cells have a single large nucleus with a characteristic folded or grooved nucleus (coffee-bean appearance) with small inconspicuous nucleoli. Birbeck granules are seen in the cytoplasm. The tumour cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a and langerin (CD207) markers.

The image below shows a histopathological image of Langerhans cells with folded nuclei.

The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

Birbeck granules have a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket–like appearance. It contains the protein langerin (CD207). It is seen on electron microscopy. The image below shows Birbeck granules on electron microscopy seen in LCH.

The below image shows lytic lesion of skull seen in LCH.

Option A: Rosai-Dorfman syndrome is otherwise called sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy. Rosai-Dorfman disease is not a histiocytic neoplasm. It is an idiopathic disease characterized by Painless lymphadenopathy, usually of cervical nodes. The disorder predominantly affects children, adolescents, and young adults. It may present with nonspecific symptoms and management mostly involves observation rather than specific treatment.  

Option B: Kimura disease is s a chronic inflammatory disorder of unknown etiology that most commonly presents as painless lymphadenopathy.

Option D: Juvenile xanthogranuloma is a non-Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurring in early infancy and childhood. It presents as reddish-brown papular lesions, which evolve to become orange. The lesions are most frequently seen in the face, scalp, and upper torso. They may be single or multiple lesions. Single lesions are the most common. The characteristic multinucleated giant cell, Touton cell is observed in 85% of juvenile xanthogranulomas.

questions.text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A was reported from a town between June and September of a particular year. The peak of the outbreak occurred in July. What is this an example of?
questions.solution:
This outbreak of viral hepatitis A is an example of a common source, multiple exposure type of epidemic.

The incubation period of hepatitis A is approximately 28 days (range 15 to 50 days). In this scenario, the cases of viral hepatitis A have occurred over a period from June to September (120 days) which is more than one incubation period of the disease. This is suggestive of multiple exposures from a common source.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is common source ,single exposure or point source epidemic.

questions.text: What type of joint is an incudostapedial joint?
questions.solution:
The incudostapedial joint is a ball and socket type of joint.

In ball and socket-type of joints, the articular surfaces include a globular head (male surface) fitting into a cup-shaped socket (female surface). These joints are multi-axial and movements occur around a number of axes. Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, medial rotation, lateral rotation, and circumduction, all occur quite freely. E.g., shoulder joint, hip joint, talocalcaneonavicular joint, and incudostapedial joint.

Note: The other joint between the incus and malleus (incudomalleolar joint) is a saddle joint.

questions.text: A 45-year old man who was a chronic alcoholic presented with confusion, ataxia, and diplopia. What is the treatment protocol?

choices.text: Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of wernicke's encephalopathy and treatment is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose containing IV fluids.

The patient's symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and diplopia strongly suggest Wernicke's encephalopathy, a neurological disorder commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol abuse. This condition arises due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which impairs the function of the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme. The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Thiamine is an essential cofactor for the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase, a key component of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex that converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. This conversion is critical for linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle, thereby facilitating energy production in the body.

Without sufficient thiamine, the activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase is severely impaired, leading to an accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood, causing lactic acidosis. This biochemical disturbance contributes to the neurological symptoms observed. Immediate administration of thiamine is crucial in treating Wernicke's encephalopathy. If left untreated, the condition can progress to Korsakoff syndrome, a chronic and debilitating memory disorder. Thus, recognizing the signs and symptoms early and providing thiamine supplementation can lead to rapid improvement and prevent long-term complications.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

    1. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by :

  • Global confusion
  • Truncal ataxia
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Horizontal nystagmus 

    2. Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include:

  • Memory loss
  • Confabulation

    3. Beriberi: It can present with sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, and muscle weakness (dry beriberi) or tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure (wet beriberi).

questions.text: In the following natural history of disease flowchart, point A to C is called?
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C) is called as lead time.

Other options:

The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the final critical point of diagnosis (point B) is called Screening time.

Screening is the search for unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applicable tests or procedures. It must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis (point C in the image).

This ensures the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. The final critical point (point B in the image) is the stage beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful or there would be permanent damage.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening which is the period between diagnosis by early detection and diagnosis by other means.

questions.text: A patient presented with itchy lesions as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules are characteristic of lichen planus.

Lichen planus is a type of lichenoid disorder affecting the papillary dermis. It is a T-cell-mediated autoimmune disease against the basal keratinocytes. It is a chronic disease with a number of relapses and remissions.

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules. This description is known as the characteristic "6 P"s of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

Clinically, oral lichen planus can present as Wickham striae (image below), white papules, white plaque, erythema, erosion, or blisters. They may be symmetrical and bilateral. Buccal mucosa, dorsum of the tongue, and gingivae are commonly affected. Early diagnosis and management play an important role in the prevention of progression to malignancy.

Complications of lichen planus include:

  • Hair: Patches of cicatricial scarring alopecia
  • Nails: Various nail changes are seen associated with lichen planus. 
    • Dorsal Nail Pterygium: The most specific nail change in lichen planus where the fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium formation.
    • Thinning of the nail plate: The most common nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions.
    • Pup-tent sign: Elevation of the nail in the shape of a tent
    • Trachonychia: All 20 nails of hands and feet undergo dystrophy
    • Subungual hyperkeratosis and onycholysis
    • Longitudinal melanonychia in lichen planus of the nail bed
    • Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)
  • Mucous membranes: Squamous cell carcinoma may occur on the lip, buccal mucosa, or gum margin.

Other options: 

Option A: Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei var. Hominis. The characteristic symptoms of a scabies infection include intense itching and superficial burrows usually in the area of the finger webs, feet, ventral wrists, elbows, back, breasts, buttocks, and external genitals. Burrows presents as slightly raised brownish linear or s-shaped tracks in the skin created by the excavation of the adult mite in the epidermis as depicted below.


Option C: Psoriasis is characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces.

questions.text: Which of the following stages of Entamoeba histolytica is considered an infective form?
questions.solution:
The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of E. histolytica. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.

Humans acquire infection by ingestion of food and water contaminated with mature quadrinucleate cyst in the feces. So, a mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form. The ameboid trophozoite is the only form present in tissues. The cytoplasm may contain red blood cells which is a pathognomonic feature.

It can manifest as acute intestinal amebiasis with symptoms of dysentery, lower abdominal discomfort, and flatulence. Low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue are present in chronic amebiasis.

The amebic ulcer which is flask-shaped is the typical lesion seen in intestinal amebiasis. The ulcers are multiple and are confined to the colon. Sometimes, in secondary intestinal lesions, the ulcers are numerous in the cecum, followed by the sigmoid-rectal region. A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon.

The most common extraintestinal manifestation is amebic hepatitis or liver abscess. The contents are necrotic and bacteriologically sterile, with active amebae confined to the walls. A characteristic anchovy paste is produced in the abscess and seen on surgical drainage

Other options:

Option A: Trophozoite is the active, feeding, and motile stage of E. histolytica that lives in the intestine. However, trophozoites are not the infective form as they cannot survive outside the host’s body due to their sensitivity to environmental conditions.

Option C: Binucleate cyst is an immature cyst, which contains only two nuclei. It is not fully developed and therefore not infective.

Option D: Metacystic trophozoites are the trophozoites that emerge from the cyst after excystation in the host’s intestine. They are not infective outside the body, as they represent a post-infection stage.

questions.text: What is the value of plasma clearance of glucose in uncontrolled diabetes?
questions.solution:
In uncontrolled diabetes, the plasma clearance of glucose is greater than zero. 

Normally, all the glucose that is filtered is reabsorbed and no glucose is excreted in the urine. Hence, the clearance is zero. In uncontrolled diabetes, since the plasma glucose concentration is greater than the renal threshold for reabsorbtion, excess glucose is excreted in the urine and the clearance is greater than zero.

Clearance of different substances can be shown in a graph as follows: 

The above graph depicts renal handling of glucose, inulin, and para-aminohippurate (PAH) and can be explained as follows:

Glucose clearance: Normally, all the glucose that is filtered is reabsorbed and no glucose is excreted in the urine. Hence, the clearance is zero. In uncontrolled diabetes, since the plasma glucose concentration is greater than the renal threshold for reabsorbtion, excess glucose is excreted in the urine and the clearance is greater than zero.

Inulin clearance: Inulin is freely filtered and is neither reabsorbed nor secreted. Hence, it is constant and equal to the glomerular filtration rate.

PAH clearance: PAH is both filtered and secreted. When plasma PAH is low, clearance is high. However, as plasma PAH rises above the threshold level for PAH secretion, clearance falls progressively.

questions.text: By which mechanism does gene repair occur when mediated by CRISPR-Cas9?
questions.solution:
Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ) repair is the major mechanism used by CRISPR-Cas9 for gene repair.

The CRISPR(Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats) are clustered palindromic sequences found in many bacteria, a form of acquired immunity to infection by bacteriophages which complements the system of restriction endonucleases and methylases  CRISPR uses RNA-based targeting to bring the Cas9 endonuclease to foreign (or any complementary) DNA. Within bacteria this CRISPR-RNA-Cas9 complex then degrades and inactivates the targeted DNA.

The CRISPR system has been adapted for use in eukaryotic cells for gene deletion, gene editing and even modulation of gene transcription. 

The guide RNA targets and binds to specific complementary sequences of DNA which are then cleaved by Cas9. Following cleavage of the targeted DNA sequence, the natural DNA repair process (Non homologous end joining repair )can be allowed to proceed or a new sequence can be inserted as shown in the image below.

The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2020 was awarded jointly to Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer A. Doudna "for the development of the CRISPR/Cas9 gene-editing system, which has for the first time enabled scientists to make precise changes in the long stretches of DNA.

questions.text: Barosinusitis is seen with respect to which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Barosinusitis occurs due to the sudden expansion of air in the sinuses, which occurs in decompression sickness.

Decompression sickness (Caisson's Disease)

When pressure increases, air gets compressed and its solubility increases. When the external pressure decreases, air becomes less soluble and expands. When a deep sea diver ascends rapidly, external pressure on the body decreases this leads to sudden expansion of air in various parts of the body leading to the following symptoms:

  • Barotitis: due to the expansion of the middle ear air chamber
  • Barodantalgia: expansion of air beneath teeth
  • Barosinusitis: expansion of the sinuses
  • Abdominal distension due to distension of the loops
  • Emphysema 

Nitrogen effervescence causes

  • Chokes: dyspnoea
  • Bends- joint pain
  • Prickles: nerve irritation

Definitive treatment for Caisson's disease is recompression.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of hypopigmentation of the skin. On examination, there was hypopigmentation of the iris. Investigations reveal neutropenia. A peripheral smear was done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows giant inclusions in polymorphonuclear neutrophils, which along with oculocutaneous albinism, and neutropenia is suggestive of Chediak-Higashi syndrome. 

It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to loss-of-function mutation of the LYST gene encoding a protein known as lysosomal trafficking regulator. There is a defective fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes, resulting in defective phagocyte function and susceptibility to infections.

Clinical features occur due to defective transport of cell products. These include:

  • Significant pyogenic infections
  • Albinism (due to abnormalities of melanocytes)
  • Neurological abnormalities
    • Progressive intellectual decline
    • Cranial nerve palsies
    • Decreased deep tendon reflexes
    • Tremor
    • Abnormal gait (nerve cell dysfunction),
  • Bleeding (due to platelet dysfunction).

Peroxidase‐positive giant inclusions are seen in leukocytes. The only curative treatment available for Chédiak–Higashi syndrome is bone marrow transplantation.

Other options

Option A: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency results in the failure of leukocyte adhesion to endothelium, preventing the cells from migrating into tissues. This results in recurrent bacterial infections.

Option B: Chronic granulomatous disease is due to a defect in phagocytes oxidase which is required for the generation of superoxide. Its defect results in recurrent infections with catalase-positive microbes.

Option C: Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection, resulting in early death.

questions.text: A man was found to be lying dead on the ground. His friend saw a snake passing in the area and took a picture of it and showed it to the doctor (image below). What is the most probable cause of death of this man?
questions.solution:
The snake in the given image with single white bands on the body is a Common krait which is neurotoxic and the most probable cause of death in this patient is respiratory failure. 

Bites of elapidae (Cobras, Kraits, Mambas, Coral Snakes) present with a local bite reaction which is generally mild with minimal swelling, blistering or superficial necrosis. Muscles of deglutition become progressively flaccidly paralyzed. A respiratory arrest may occur due to obstruction of the upper airway by the paralysed tongue or inhaled vomitus, or due to paralysis of intercostal muscles and diaphragm.

questions.text: In the pressure–volume graph shown below, compliance of lung is represented by _________.
questions.solution:
In the given pressure-volume graph, curve B represents lung compliance. Curve A corresponds to chest compliance, while curve C indicates the combined compliance of both the lung and chest wall.

The equilibrium position is at functional residual capacity (FRC), where the expanding force on the chest wall is exactly equal to the collapsing force on the lungs. FRC is also known as relaxation volume and represents the amount of air remaining in the lungs at the end of normal expiration.

At the point where volume= FRC,

  • Intraalveolar pressure is equal to atmospheric pressure and considered as zero.
  • Intrapleural pressure is negative (-2.5 mmHg)
  • Transpulmonary pressure = Intraalveolar pressure – intrapleural pressure = 0 – (-2.5 mmHg) = +2.5 mmHg.  

For compliance of lung – Pressure considered is Transpulmonary pressure. So at FRC, Transpulmonary pressure is positive (+2.5 mmHg). Hence, B indicates compliance of lung.  

For compliance of chest wall – Pressure considered is intrapleural – atmospheric pressure. At FRC, this value is -2.5 mmHg. Hence, A represents compliance of the chest wall.  

When the volume is FRC, the combined lung and chest-wall curve intersects the X-axis at an airway pressure of zero. Hence, C represents the combined chest wall and lung compliance.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with fever, sore throat, polyarthralgia, erythema marginatum, and chest pain. A rapid streptococcal antigen is found to be positive. Physical examination is remarkable for a loud friction rub. Which of the following is most likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. Serous pericarditis is seen in acute rheumatic fever.

Serous pericarditis is associated with conditions such as rheumatic fever, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), systemic scleroderma, tumors, uremia, viral infections, or tuberculosis. It involves mild inflammation of the epicardial and pericardial surfaces, characterized by both acute and chronic inflammatory cells. The condition leads to the exudation of serous fluid, typically ranging from 50 to 200 mL, which develops slowly and rarely affects cardiac function.

Other options:

Option A: Suppurative (purulent) pericarditis caused by bacterial, mycotic, or parasitic invasion of the pericardial space. The infection can spread through direct extension, blood seeding, lymphatic spread, or instrumentation. This form of pericarditis may extend into the surrounding mediastinum and typically results in the formation of adhesions, leading to constrictive pericarditis with significant clinical consequences.

Option C: Hemorrhagic pericarditis is most commonly seen in cases of tuberculosis or malignant neoplasms, particularly from the lung or breast, and can also occur after cardiac surgery.

Option D: Caseous pericarditis is almost always tubercular in origin.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy developed a sudden onset weakness of the left side of the body with facial deviation to the right side. On examination, he was tall and thin with elongated limbs and an ocular finding is shown in the image below. What is the most likely inborn error of metabolism in this child?
questions.solution:
This child who is tall with and elongated limbs combined with the image finding of ectopia lentis most likely has homocystinuria. Homocystinuria is an important cause of thromboembolic disease and thus, pediatric stroke. The image in the question shows ectopia lentis, usually the first manifestation of disease. It is most commonly caused by a defect in the cystathionine β synthase enzyme leading to the accumulation of homocysteine in urine and blood. They are generally normal at birth and the first sign is subluxation of the lens (ectopia lentis) seen after 3 years of age.

Clinical features of homocystinuria include ectopia lentis (Downward and outward eye), Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorders, Thromboembolic episodes, skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome, tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly.

Elevations of both methionine and homocysteine in body fluids are the diagnostic laboratory findings. The diagnosis is established by molecular analysis of cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) or by assay of the enzyme in cultured fibroblasts, phytohemagglutinin-stimulated lymphocytes, or liver biopsy specimens. Treatment includes restriction of methionine intake and supplementation with cysteine, betaine, vitamins B6, B12, and folate.

The image depicts downward subluxation of the lens and the given clinical scenario is suggestive of homocystinuria.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presents with an injury resulting from blunt force trauma. As the attending emergency medical officer, how would you record the wound description in the case sheet?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a wound with linear splitting of the tissue, sharp margins, and crushed hair follicles, which is suggestive of an incised-looking lacerated wound. 

Incised-looking lacerated wounds are seen at sites where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue. A blunt force causes linear splitting of the tissue which results in the laceration resembling an incised wound. There will be extensive tissue crushing but the margins will be clear and delineable. 

Common areas are Scalp, Forehead, Eyebrows, Zygoma, Lower jaw, Perineum, Shin, and Iliac crest.

Laceration (Option-A)

A laceration is a tear or a split in the skin, mucous membrane, muscle, or any internal organ produced by blunt force. The full thickness of the skin is penetrated.

Features of laceration:

  • Margins are irregular with pieces of tissue attached in between called tissue tags or bridges. Tears that are seen at the ends, diverging away from the main laceration are called swallow tails.
  • Bruising is seen around the margins.
  • Deeper tissues are unevenly divided with tissue tags.
  • Hair bulbs are crushed.
  • Depth of the wound contains abundant foreign material such as dust particles, paint material of the vehicle involved, etc
  • In skin lacerations, usually one of the margins overhangs the other. This helps in assessing the direction of the force.
  • A laceration, on healing, produces a permanent scar.

Classification of a laceration:

  • Split laceration (incised - like laceration)
    • This occurs when the skin is crushed between two hard objects
    • For example, during a fall, the scalp gets crushed between the skull from inside and hard ground outside. This results in a wound, which usually mimics an incised one unless examined closely.
  • Stretch laceration
    • As the name implies, it occurs due to the over-stretching of the skin, beyond its elasticity.
    • This typically occurs in the setting of a fracture, where the fracture fragment may stretch and pierce the skin to project out
  • Avulsed laceration
    • An avulsion is a lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues. It may overhang the wound.
    • This is common in road traffic accidents.
  • Tears - Tearing of skin and subcutaneous tissue can occur from localized impact
  • Cuts - Injury leads to a deep and wide injury leading to a cut

Incised wound (Option-B)

An incised wound is a clean-cut wound made with a sharp-edged instrument, through the skin and subcutaneous tissues, including blood vessels. It is more in length than depth. The edges are well-defined and usually everted, free from contusions and abrasions. It is generally spindle-shaped. The depth is more at the commencement and progressively becomes shallower, known as tailing. Tailing determines the direction of the force applied when creating the wound.

The image below shows two spindle-shaped incisions.

 

Laceration-looking incised wounds (Option C)

In areas of the body where a loose layer of muscle fibres is attached to the skin, the edges of the incision may become inverted, adherent, and wrinkled leading to it simulating a lacerated wound. Such wounds are called lacerated-looking incised wounds. These are commonly seen in Scrotum and Axilla.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency room after being evacuated from a collapsed building during an earthquake. He is unconscious and has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8. Imaging of the head reveals the following findings. Which color code will you triage him in?
questions.solution:
The CT scan finding of a biconvex lentiform hyperdensity that does not cross suture lines is suggestive of an extradural hematoma. With a GCS score of 8, the patient should be triaged as red as management requires emergency surgery. 

Triage is done based on a preliminary assessment of patients to determine the urgency of treatment. Patients are prioritized based on the severity of their injuries and the likelihood of survival with prompt medical treatment. It is particularly useful in case of mass casualties to prevent health facilities from getting overwhelmed. 

Red indicated a high priority of treatment or an immediate transfer to higher health facilities. These patients may survive if they receive timely medical intervention. 

An extradural hematoma with a GCS score of < or = 8 necessitates emergent surgery in the form of craniotomy, hematoma evacuation, and ligation of the injured vessel. Early surgery is associated with good neurological outcomes.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with Trendelenburg sign positive on one side. Which of the following muscles are involved?

choices.text: Lateral rotators of the hip joint

questions.solution:
The muscles involved in a positive Trendelenburg sign are the hip abductors—the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus.

The gluteus medius and minimus are powerful abductors of the hip supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Stabilizing the pelvis on the femur during walking is done by these muscles. It is demonstrated by asking the subject to stand on one limb. If the ipsilateral abductors are normal, the pelvis remains in a horizontal position. If the ipsilateral abductors are weak, then the pelvis tilts towards the opposite (unsupported) side. This is called positive Trendelenburg’s sign.

Other causes of positive Trendelenburg signs include shortening of the femoral neck, abductor tendon rupture, and dislocation or subluxation of the hip joint. 

Patients are known to have a characteristic gait, which is called Trendelenburg or waddling gait. The trunk is thrown from side to side with each step, and the patient lurches toward the unaffected limb while walking.

questions.text: Match the following eggs to the organisms given in the table below.
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

The Hymenolepis nana egg is roughly spherical or ovoid. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore that encloses the hexacanth oncosphere. They are non-bile-stained. The eggs float in the saturated salt solution. 

The image below shows an egg of H. nana.

 

Ascaris lumbricoides (Roundworm) are round or oval in shape. They are always bile-stained which gives them golden-brown color. The eggs float in a saturated salt solution. They have a thick smooth translucent shell with:

  • an outer coarsely mammillated albuminous coat
  • a thick transparent middle layer, and
  • an inner lipoidal vitelline membrane.

The unfertilized eggs of Ascaris are elliptical, narrower, and contain a small atrophied ovum. It has a mass of disorganized refractile granules. The shell is thinner and the egg does not float in a saturated salt solution

The image below shows the egg of A. lumbricoides.

 

The egg of Ancylostoma duodenale or hookworm is oval or elliptical. They are colorless, not bile-stained. The eggs are surrounded by a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane. It contains a segmented ovum, usually with 4-8 blastomeres. There is a clear space between the ovum and the shell. It floats in the saturated salt solution. The image below shows the egg of A. duodenale.

 

The eggs of Taenia solium and Taenia saginata are indistinguishable. The egg is spherical. The inner embryophore is radially striated and is yellow-brown due to bile staining. A fully-developed embryo (oncosphere) with three pairs of hooklets (hexacanth embryo) is present in the center.

The eggs of T. saginata are infective only to cattle and not to humans, whereas the eggs of T. solium are infective to pigs and humans. The eggs do not float in a saturated salt solution. The image below shows the egg of Taenia.

Pseudo-Meigs syndrome, which presents with ascites and pleural effusion in association with benign tumors of the ovary, other than fibromas (E.g. Thecoma, Granulosa cell tumor, Brenner tumor) and Leiomyomas.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presented with a complaint of lower backache. The MRI of her lumbosacral spine is given below. Her bone mineral density is measured, and her T-score is -2.8. She is given oral drugs, but she develops esophagitis. Which of the following intravenous treatment plans would be useful in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is diagnostic of postmenopausal osteoporosis and Zoledronate 5 mg intravenous annually is used in the management of this condition.

Zoledronate belongs to a class of drugs called bisphosphonates. Bisphosphonates inhibit bone resorption by inducing osteoclast apoptosis at sites of active bone remodeling. 

Routes of administration:

  • Etidronate, alendronate, risedronate, and tiludronate : oral
  • Zoledronate, ibandronate, and pamidronate : IV

Intravenous formulations are given when oral formulations cannot be taken due to side effects like esophagitis.

Therapeutic uses of Zoledronate:

  • Treatment of peri menopausal osteoporosis: 5 mg IV annually (intravenous infusion for over 15 minutes)
  • Treatment of Paget's disease:  A single 5-mg infusion
  • Prevention of osteoporosis in hormone-treated prostate and breast cancer
  • For the treatment of multiple myeloma, bone metastases from solid tumors, or hypercalcemia of malignancy: 4 mg IV

Other options:

Options A and B - Teriparatide is a recombinant parathormone analog that has an anabolic effect on bone homeostasis when given intermittently. It acts by increasing osteoblastic activity. It increases bone mineral density and decreases the risk of fractures in postmenopausal women. It is administered as a subcutaneous injection of 20 μg once daily.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought with fever, fatigue, and left ventricular dysfunction. An endomyocardial biopsy is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child with complaints of fever, fatigue, and left ventricular dysfunction, and a biopsy showing lymphocytic infiltration in myocardial tissue, is suggestive of lymphocytic myocarditis.

The inflammatory process of the myocardium is termed myocarditis. Patients mostly present with fatigue, chest pain, cardiogenic shock, and even cardiac arrest. Viruses are the most common among the infectious causes of myocarditis. Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis, and it shows diffuse, mononuclear, lymphocytic infiltration, as shown below.

Myocarditis begins with the direct invasion of an infectious agent. It subsequently replicates within and around the myocardium, causing myonecrosis. 

They are treated with supportive management. 

Other Options:

Option A: Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

This condition classically occurs a few weeks after an episode of group A streptococcal pharyngitis or, less commonly, skin infections, and Aschoff's bodies are seen in the image below.

Option B: The myocarditis of Chagas disease has distinctive features of the parasitization of scattered myofibers by trypanosomes accompanied by a mixed inflammatory infiltrate of neutrophils, lymphocytes, macrophages, and occasional eosinophils. The clusters of amastigotes cause swelling of individual myocardial fibers and create intracellular pseudocysts. There is focal myocardial cell necrosis accompanied by extensive, dense, acute interstitial inflammatory infiltration throughout the heart.

The image below shows the amastigotes within a myocyte (arrow) and the surrounding inflammatory response.

Option C- In most bacterial infections, the heart can be involved through direct invasion and abscess formation. Causes include diphtheria, brucellosis, legionella, Meningococcus, and Mycoplasma, and require treatment of the systemic infection.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was brought to the casualty with a 3-day history of the findings shown. On examination, 50% of the body surface area was involved. Hemorrhagic cheilitis and crusting were also noted. What are the diagnosis and most probable underlying etiology?

choices.text: Stevens Johnson syndrome; Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection

questions.solution:
The given scenario of a serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes involving more than 30% of the body surface is suggestive of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Carbamazepine is commonly associated with SJS/TEN.

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS involves <10% of the body surface) and Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN involves >30% of the body surface) are primarily a drug‐induced phenomenon, with a culprit drug being demonstrated in approximately 85% of cases.

Common drugs that can cause SJS/TEN are:

  • Allopurinol
  • NSAIDs - oxicam group
  • Anti-epileptics - phenobarbital, phenytoin, carbamazepine, lamotrigine
  • Antibiotics - penicillins, cephalosporins, sulfamethoxazole, sulfasalazine, nevirapine

In 15% of the cases, where the drug cannot be identified, especially in children, it appear to be triggered by infections, most notably by Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Note: FDA recommends genotyping before starting carbamazepine, as the HLA B1502 allele which is seen in increased frequencies among Asians is implicated in carbamazepine-induced SJS/TEN.

Other options :

Stevens Johnson syndrome is a drug-induced condition characterized by widespread epithelial keratinocyte necrosis of both skin and mucous membranes. It is due to cytotoxic T-lymphocytes. SJS with extensive involvement of skin (more than 30% of body surface area) is considered toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). The most common drugs involved in SJS/TEN are allopurinol, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, nevirapine, oxicam nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, phenobarbital, phenytoin, sulfamethoxazole, and sulfasalazine.

The length of a septic tank is twice its breadth.The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m. The recommended depth of liquid is 1.2m. The tank has an inlet and outlet pipe along with a concrete cover. Septic tanks are usually designed to have a retention period of 24 hours.

questions.text: You are a part of a water purification program, where you are explaining chlorine as a disinfectant. Which among the following is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection?
questions.solution:
Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection.

Action of chlorine:

When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric acid (HCl) and hypochlorous acids (HOCl), as follows.

H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl

The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water.

The hypochlorous acid (HOCl) ionizes to form hydrogen ions (H+) and hypochlorite ions (OCl-), as follows:

HOCl → H+ + OCl-

The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid, which is 70-80 times more effective than the hypochlorite ions.

The formation of hypochlorous acid is predominant, when the pH of the water is around 7. If the pH exceeds 8.5, chlorine is unreliable as a disinfectant, as about 90% of the hypochlorous acid that is formed gets ionized to hypochlorite ions.

Most waters have a pH between 6 to 7.5.

questions.text: In a patient, the hypothalamic thermostat was reset from point A to point C as shown below. Which of the following happens in stage A compared to stage B?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient's hypothalamic thermostat has been reset from point A to a higher temperature (point C). The body responds to this change by using certain measures in stage A such as shivering.

In stage A the body activates various heat gain mechanisms to match the hypothalamic temperature setpoint. These include:

  • Shivering- the shivering center is located in the posterior hypothalamus. It is normally inhibited by signals from the heat center in the anterior hypothalamic-preoptic area but is excited by cold signals from the skin and spinal cord. A sudden increase in heat setpoint results in the activation of this center. It then transmits non-rhythmic signals through bilateral tracts through the lateral columns of the spinal cord, and finally to the anterior motor neurons. They increase the tone of the skeletal muscles throughout the body. As the tone rises above a certain critical level, shivering begins. During maximum shivering, body heat production can rise to four to five times normal.
  • Vasoconstriction (decreased blood flow to skin) is mediated by increased sympathetic drive by the activation of the posterior hypothalamic sympathetic center.
  • An increase in chemical thermogenesis in which heat production takes place in the brown fat by the mechanism of uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation. This is the predominant mechanism seen in neonates.

In stage B, the hypothalamic temperature setpoint is lower than the normal body temperature. Hence body activates various heat loss mechanisms to match the hypothalamic temperature setpoint. It includes vasodilatation of the skin blood vessel, sweating, and decreased thermogenesis.

The temperature of the body is regulated majorly by a nervous feedback mechanism that operates through temperature-regulating centers located in the hypothalamus. Minor regulation is done by the thermal receptors in the skin and the deep thermal receptors present in the spinal cord and abdominal viscera.

questions.text: Which of the following is the action of the lateral pterygoid muscle?
questions.solution:
The action of the lateral pterygoid muscle is depression, protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the jaw.

In addition, lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted into the articular disc and capsule of TMJ.

Lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - It originates from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the infratemporal surface of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone.
  • Insertion - The muscle inserts into the neck of the condyle of the mandible and the articular disc and capsule of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

Masseter muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of the zygomatic bone and zygomatic arch.
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the lateral surface of the ramus of the mandible and coronoid process

Temporalis muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from the temporal fossa and deep surface of the temporal fascia.
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the coronoid process and to the anterior border of the ramus of the mandible up to the third molar tooth.

Lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - The upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. 
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule of the temporomandibular joint, and articular disc.

 Medial pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Deep head arises from the medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone. The superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and pyramidal process of palatine bone
  • Insertion- It is inserted into the medial surface of the ramus, near the angle of the mandible.

questions.text: The diagram shows the enzymes responsible for converting pyruvate to acetyl CoA. What are the enzymes labeled E1 and E2, respectively?
questions.solution:
E1 is pyruvate dehydrogenase and E2 is dihydrolipoyl transacetylase in the image showing oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate. This is catalyzed by the pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex where E1, E2, and E3 are the three enzyme components of the complex. 

The pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane. It catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA which enters the citric acid/Kreb’s cycle. 

Enzyme components of PDH complex                        Co-factors
Pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1) Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)
Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase (E2)

Lipoic acid

Coenzyme A
Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (E3)

Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)

Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+)


Steps of pyruvate decarboxylation:

  • Pyruvate is transported into the mitochondria by a proton symporter.
  • Pyruvate is decarboxylated by pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1). TPP is required for this step. The decarboxylated pyruvate remains bound to the enzyme, as hydroxyethyl thiamine pyrophosphate.
  • The hydroxyethyl group is oxidized to form an acetyl group. It is then transferred from TPP to lipoamide to form acetyl lipoamide. This step is catalyzed by dihydrolipoyl transacetylase (E2).
  • Acetyl lipoamide reacts with coenzyme A to form acetyl-CoA and reduced lipoamide. 
  • The reduced lipoamide is reoxidized by FAD-dependent dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (E3). 

        The overall reaction is : Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2

 

Clinical significance:

  1. Dietary deficiency of thiamine inhibits PDH. Chronic alcoholics may develop potentially fatal pyruvic and lactic acidosis. Lactic acidosis is a common presentation in patients with inherited pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency too. 
  2. In arsenic and mercury poisoning, the heavy metal ions react with -SH groups of lipoic acid and inhibit pyruvate dehydrogenase.

Other multienzyme complexes include alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase and branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase. All the five coenzymes of PDH are common to these two complexes too.

questions.text: What is the most likely enzyme deficiency in an 8-month-old infant presenting with irritability, vomiting, seizures, jaundice, hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, and abnormal findings on Benedict’s test following the recent introduction of cereals and fruit juices into the diet?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario the diagnosis is hereditary fructose intolerance and enzyme defective is Aldolase-B.

Aldolase B converts fructose-1-phosphate to glyceraldehyde. The deficiency of aldolase B results in the accumulation of fructose 1-phosphate. This decreases the levels of inorganic phosphate and ATPs. ATP is required for gluconeogenesis and protein synthesis. Therefore, the patient presents with hypoglycemia and acidosis. 

Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). They present with profound hypoglycemia and vomiting after ingestion of fructose-containing foods. If the condition is not treated it might lead to the impairment of liver functioning.

Diagnosis is made by detecting reducing sugars in the urine, enzyme assay, or DNA testing for the mutations in the ALDOB gene. Once the diagnosis of HFI is made, the source of fructose must be removed from the diet.

The given image below shows the metabolism of fructose and pathophysiological mechanism of development of hereditary fructose intolerance.

 

Other options :

Option a : Fructokinase converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. Patients with a deficiency of this enzyme are usually asymptomatic as the accumulated fructose is eliminated from urine. This condition is called essential fructosuria.

Option c and d : Deficiency of galactose 1-phosphate uridyl transferase and galactokinase can result in similar symptoms. But it starts as soon as breastfeeding is initiated as the patient cannot metabolise galactose present in the breastmilk. The affected children might also have cataracts due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens.

Abiciximab is an anti platelet drug. Other drugs that act by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors are tirofiban and eptifibatide. They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

Deficiency of the same receptor, Glycoprotein IIb-IIIa, leads to a condition called immune thrombocytopenic purpura. In immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), antibodies are formed in the spleen against the cell-surface antigens GpIIb/IIIa or GpIb/IX, causing increased peripheral destruction of platelets.
