questions.text: In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate should exceed?
questions.solution:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) should exceed 60%. This coincides with every couple having 2 children.

Net reproduction rate (NRR) is defined as the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rate. India is aiming for an NRR of 1 as it is equivalent to the two-child norm. 

CPR measures the prevalence of contraceptive use in eligible couples, who are currently married and the wife is in the reproductive age group of 15 to 45 years.  It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning like sterilization, IUD, oral pills or condoms. Sterilization is considered the most effective form of contraception. It accounts for over 60% of effectively protected couples.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient, who has been a chronic smoker for 14 years, came to the hospital seeking treatment to quit smoking. Varenicline, a medication that targets nicotinic receptors, was prescribed. How does this drug act on the nicotinic receptors?
questions.solution:
Varenicline acts as an α4β2 partial agonist on the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. 

Varenicline is a synthetic drug with partial agonistic activity at α4β2, α3β4 and α6β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. It acts as a full agonist at α7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. It reduces cigarette craving and long term abstinence rates. The high receptor affinity of varenicline blocks access to nicotine and acts as a reward in patients with relapse thus maintaining the abstinence.

Varenicline is associated with suicidal ideation, mood and behavioural changes, increased risk of cardiovascular disease.

Another drug used in the nicotine addiction is the cytisine, a plant alkaloid and partial agonist at α4β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

Other drugs used in treatment of nicotine deaddiction are:

  • Nicotine replacement therapy reduces craving and physical withdrawal symptoms during cessation. It is available as gums, lozenges, transdermal patches, nasal sprays and vapor inhalers.
  • Bupropion is a weak dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor that is helpful in nicotine deaddiction.

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text:
On ultrasound, a fetus was found to have intrauterine growth restriction, with the head circumference relatively preserved compared to length and weight. This type of growth restriction would have occurred due to all of the following causes except

TORCH: Toxoplasmosis, Other agents, such as syphilis or hepatitis B, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, Herpes simplex
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of asymmetric intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), which would have been caused by all the above conditions except TORCH infections, which cause symmetric IUGR.

Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) refers to a deficiency of fetal growth and an abnormal fetal growth trajectory. It is often classified as 

Symmetric IUGR:

  • Insult on fetal growth occurs early.
  • As a result, head circumference, length, and weight are equally affected.
  • It can be due to genetic causes, chromosomal disorders, or TORCH infections in the fetus.

Asymmetric IUGR

  • Insult occurs in late gestation, producing a relative brain-sparing effect.
  • The Head circumference is relatively preserved compared to weight and length.
  • It is caused by placental insufficiency, pregnancy-induced hypertension(PIH), poor maternal nutrition, or maternal medical diseases (option A,B and C)

Severe maternal hypertension causes symmetric IUGR while late-onset maternal vascular disease(PIH, preeclampsia) causes asymmetric IUGR.

questions.text: A patient developed lesions after 10 days of taking a specific medication. They also report having similar lesions on the soles of their feet, which are sensitive to touch. What is the most likely drug responsible for this side effect?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts classical findings of hand foot syndrome and capecitabine is commonly associated with this prominent side effect.

Hand foot syndrome or palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia consists of erythema, desquamation, pain and sensitivity to touch of the palms and soles. Drugs commonly implicated are:

  • Capecitabine
  • 5-Fluorouracil
  • Cytarabine
  • Pemetrexed
  • Doxorubicin

Other options :

Option a : Cisplatin is a platinum-containing chemotherapeutic agent. It is non-cell cycle specific and causes cross-linking of DNA to kill tumor cells. A copper transporter CTR1 is involved in the entry of platinum complexes into these cells. It is however a highly emetic drug and antiemetics are routinely administered before infusing it. Other adverse effects include dose-dependent nephrotoxicity which can be prevented by the agent amifostine and by hydration with normal saline before drug infusion. It is an ototoxic drug that can cause tinnitus and hearing loss. It is also known to cause peripheral neuropathy and hyperuricemia. 

Option b : Vincristine prevents the polymerization of microtubular protein tubulin, causing metaphase arrest. It is very useful for inducing remission in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Prominent adverse effects are peripheral neuropathy and alopecia. It also causes ataxia, nerve palsies, autonomic dysfunction and seizures.

Option d : Mitomycin-C is derived from the Streptomyces caespitosus bacteria. It can modify wound healing at a molecular level by inhibiting DNA synthesis by cross-linking DNA, acting like an alkylating agent (cell cycle non-specific). It has been used to inhibit post-surgical scar formation and as a chemotherapeutic agent for solid tumors.

questions.text:
Match the following genetic diseases with their respective trinucleotide repeat sequences.

          Genetic disease                Trinucleotide repeats

  1. Huntington’s disease               a. CGG
  2. Myotonic dystrophy                 b. GAA
  3. Friedreich ataxia                       c. CAG
  4. Fragile X syndrome                  d. CTG
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1 - c, 2 - d, 3 - b, 4 - a.

1. Huntington’s disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder. It is caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat (>40) expansion mutation in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4p. The disease shows genetic anticipation and has an early-onset (second to the third decade) if inherited from the father. Cognitive impairment is an early feature. Pathologically, atrophy of caudate and putamen with ex vacuo ventriculomegaly is seen.  Decreased acetylcholine leads to dementia and decreased GABA and increased dopamine lead to chorea.

2. Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disease caused due to triplet repeat expansion of DNA in the DMPK gene. The polynucleotide sequence involved in the expansion is the CTG sequence. This leads to an abnormal expression of myotonin protein kinase. In the childhood form of DM,intellectual disability and behavioural problems are often the predominant features. Other key findings of classic DM include, Myotonia or delay in muscle relaxation, weakness and atrophy of facial and distal limb musculature, cardiac abnormalities including cardiomyopathy and conduction disturbances, frontal hair loss, cataracts, insulin resistance.

3.  Friedreich ataxia is the most common inherited ataxia. It is an autosomal recessive cause of spinocerebellar degeneration, caused by the expansion of GAA trinucleotides on chromosome 9. Most patients have pes cavus.

4. Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males. It occurs due to CGG repeats in the untranslated regions(UTR) of the FMR1 gene.

questions.text: You are volunteering in a vaccination camp. You perform a shake test before administering a particular vaccine. Which of the following is checked by this test?
questions.solution:
The shake test is done to check for damage to vaccines that are sensitive to freezing temperatures.

Steps to perform the shake test:

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than that in the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

Some of the most widely used vaccines are freeze-sensitive. These include vaccines against:

  • Diphtheria
  • Tetanus
  • Pertussis
  • Haemophilus influenza type b (Liquid )
  • Hepatitis B

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: A young man presents with intense pruritus and has painful, red streaks between his fingers and in the groin area. He states that the itchiness is worse at night. Other members of his family also present with similar complaints. A dermoscopy of his skin is shown below. Which of the following can be used for the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a magnified view of a burrowing trail are suggestive of scabies. 5% permethrin cream is used in the management of this patient.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis. The characteristic symptoms of a scabies infection include intense itching and superficial burrows. 

Burrow is the characteristic lesion of scabies. They present as slightly raised brownish tortuous lesions. It is created by the excavation of the adult mite in the epidermis. In most people, the trails of the burrowing mites are linear in the skin.

Typical locations of lesions are the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, the elbows, the axillae, the buttocks and genitalia, and the breasts of women.

The treatment options are the topical application of 5% permethrin cream, 1% lindane lotion, benzyl benzoate, esdepalletrin (bioallethrin), crotamiton, and precipitated sulfur, and oral prescriptions like ivermectin.

All family members, even if asymptomatic need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection and the clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.

Other options:

Option B: Oral albendazole is used in the treatment of larva currens and cutaneous larva migrans. They present as pruritic erythematous papules at the site of penetration of the hookworms with an erythematous serpiginous larva track.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man is operated for a lipoma in his right arm. The swelling is excised with a clear linear incision and the wound is sutured cleanly by a junior resident. In this type of healing, neovascularization reaches its peak on day_____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is an example of healing by the first intention. Neovascularization reaches its peak by day 5 of healing by the first intention.

One of the examples of healing by the first intention is the healing of a clean uninfected surgical incision approximated by surgical sutures.

The sequence of events in wound healing is as follows:

Time after injury Events
Within 24 hours

Neutrophils:

  • Migrate from the incision margin towards the fibrin clot
  • Release proteolytic enzymes that begin to clear the debris

Basal cells: 

  • Located at the cut edge of the epidermis
  • Show increased mitotic activity
24 to 48 hours

Epithelial cells:

  • Migrate and proliferate from the wound edges towards the center 
  • Deposit basement membrane components 
  • Form a continuous epithelial layer that closes the wound
Day 3
  • Macrophages become predominant, with very few neutrophils 
  • Granulation tissue progressively invades the incision space
  • Collagen fibers at the incision margins
  • Increased thickness of the epithelial layer through continued epithelial proliferation 
Day 5
  • Neovascularization reaches its peak as granulation tissue fills the incisional space
  • As new vessels are leaky, new granulation tissue is often edematous
2nd week
  • Continued collagen accumulation
  • Fibroblast proliferation.
End of the 1st month
  • Scar contains cellular connective tissue
  • Largely devoid of inflammatory cells
  • Covered by an essentially normal epidermis

questions.text: In which of the following phases of the bacterial growth curve does sporulation occur?
questions.solution:
Sporulation occurs in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, which is marked as C in the image.

Phases of bacterial growth: 

  • Lag phase (Marked as A): Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media. Cell size increases and maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase. This initial period is the time required for adaptation to a new environment, during which the necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication to proceed.
  • Log phase or exponential phase (Marked as B): In this phase, cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 
  • Stationary phase (Marked as C): Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. It's a state of equilibrium, where the number of new cells forms equals the number of cells that die. Sporulation occurs during this phase. 
  • Phase of decline (Marked as D): In this phase, the population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

questions.text: A known smoker presenting with a cough was evaluated, and blood tests showed leukocytosis with no elevation in tumor markers. A chest x-ray revealed a mass in the right lung, and a biopsy of the mass showed the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, with the absence of tumour markers, leukocytosis, and the histopathological image showing large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and a moderate cytoplasm point to the diagnosis of large cell carcinoma of the lung. 

Large cell carcinoma is an undifferentiated malignant epithelial tumour. Typical cytologic features of other forms of lung cancer are absent. This type of lung cancer does not express any of the tumour markers associated with adenocarcinoma (TTF-1, napsin A) or squamous cell carcinoma (p40, p63). On microscopy, the features described above are observed.

Tumor-related leukocytosis is commonly seen as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with large cell carcinoma of the lung.

Other options:

Option B - Adenocarcinoma is an invasive malignant epithelial tumour. Histopathological examination shows various patterns, including acinar, papillary, lepidic, micropapillary, and solid. A histopathological image of adenocarcinoma of the lung showing glandular differentiation is given below:

Option C - Small cell carcinomas are highly malignant tumours with a strong association with cigarette smoking. Histopathological examination shows relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin in a salt-and-pepper pattern, and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The Azzopardi effect is the basophilic staining of vessel walls due to DNA residue deposited from necrotic tumour cells, as seen below:

Option D - Squamous cell carcinoma is a malignant tumour associated with smoking. Histopathological examination is characterized by the presence of keratinization and/or intercellular bridges. Keratinization is seen as squamous pearls or individual cells with markedly eosinophilic cytoplasm. There is a high mitotic activity in poorly differentiated tumours.

The image given below shows squamous pearls seen in squamous cell carcinomas.

questions.text:
A patient who consumes non-iodized salt presents with weight gain, constipation, hair loss, and fatigue for 3 months. On examination, the finding given below is seen. What is the reason for the presence of this finding?

(TSH - thyroid-stimulating hormone)
questions.solution:
The image shows the diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland known as goiter. A patient who consumes non-iodized salt and has weight gain, constipation, hair loss, and fatigue has hypothyroidism due to iodine deficiency. The reason for the presence of goiter in this condition is elevated plasma TSH levels.

Goitre is the diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland. It may be seen in hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism, and euthyroidism as well. It is caused by the action of excess TSH or substances similar to TSH on the thyroid gland. This is due to the trophic action of TSH on the thyroid gland i.e. it causes hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the follicular cells.

In patients with iodine deficiency, the production of thyroid hormones is impaired and features of hypothyroidism develop. Decreased levels of the thyroid hormones result in increased TSH secretion from the anterior pituitary via negative feedback. TSH stimulates hypertrophy and hyperplasia of follicular cells and the secretion of large amounts of thyroglobulin. Thus, the thyroid gland enlarges. This condition is known as endemic goiter.

Other causes of hypothyroidism resulting in goiter are autoimmune thyroiditis, deiodinase deficiency, and disorders of iodide trapping, peroxidase, or coupling systems. Consumption of food containing goitrogenic substances (eg: turnips, cabbages) also results in goiter.

Other options:

Option B: Wolff-Chaikoff effect is the transient inhibition of the organification of iodide when large doses of iodide are consumed. This results in a decrease in thyroid hormone synthesis.  This effect will not be seen in this patient who consumes non-iodized salt.

Option C: In Grave’s disease, TSH-receptor antibodies are present. They act similar to TSH and stimulate excessive secretion of thyroid hormones. Patients with Grave’s disease present with goiter, weight loss, exophthalmos, tremors, and tachycardia.  

Option D: Mucopolysaccharide deposition is the mechanism of myxedema formation in hypothyroid patients. The deposition results in fluid filtration out of the capillaries and the formation of non-pitting edema.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive​ patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an HIV-positive person with mucosal lesion in the mouth and microscopy showing budding yeasts and pseudohyphae is suggestive of oral candidiasis.

Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans.

It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.

It is treated with topical nystatin, oral ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

Option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

Option C: Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

Option D: Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudomembrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: A medical student is giving her histology exam. She got the following slide in the exam. What could the structure be?
questions.solution:
The above histology image shows Glomerulus.

Glomerulus is a rounded tuft of anastomosing capillaries lined by fenestrated endothelium. Blood enters the tuft through an afferent arteriole and leaves it through an efferent arteriole. It is supported by the mesangium containing mesangial cells and a non-cellular mesangial matrix.

The glomerular capillary wall is the filtering membrane and consists of fenestrated endothelial cells, basement membrane, and visceral epithelial cells called podocytes, which contain foot processes.

The image given below shows the histology of the glomerulus.

Option A: Leydig cells also known as interstitial cells of Leydig are present in the interstitial connective tissue between seminiferous tubules.

Testis contains numerous seminiferous tubules separated by connective tissue in between. Seminiferous tubules are lined by several spermatogonia cells which produce spermatozoa, and Sertoli (sustentacular) cells which have a supportive function. 

The connective tissue in between the tubules is made up of Leydig cells, collagen fibers, fibroblasts, macrophages, mast cells, blood vessels, and lymphatics. Leydig cells are large, round, or polyhedral cells with eccentric nuclei. They are lightly stained and often have a foamy appearance. They secrete testosterone upon stimulation by luteinizing hormone from the anterior pituitary.

The image below shows seminiferous tubules and Leydig cells.

Option B: Islets of Langerhans makes up the endocrine part of the pancreas.

Islets are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers, and containing numerous fenestrated capillaries. There is a delicate capsule around each islet. They are paler than the surrounding exocrine cells, as they have less rough endoplasmic reticulum.

The Islet of Langerhans is mainly composed of three types of cells:

  • α or A cells- located peripherally and secrete glucagon 
  • β or B cells- located centrally and produce insulin 
  • δ or D cells- scattered between beta cells and secrete somatostatin

The image given below shows the Islets of Langerhans.

Option C: Hassall's corpuscles are small rounded structures present in the medulla of the thymus. Each corpuscle has a central core of degenerated epithelial cells and macrophages surrounded by concentrically arranged epithelial cells. The degenerated cells ultimately give pink staining hyaline mass. The function of the corpuscles of Hassall is still not known.

questions.text: Given below is the demonstration of tetanization in the gastrocnemius muscle of a frog. Identify the tetanising frequency
questions.solution:
Tetanizing frequency demonstrated by the muscle is 33Hz. In the above graph, we know,

  • The speed of the paper is 1000mm/sec.
  • The y-axis represents millivolts, the x-axis represents time.
  • The scale on the x-axis is 10mm.
  • The area under the graph represents the muscle contraction.

Contraction period (latent period to maximum force of contraction) includes 3 scales = 30 mm. 

As paper speed is 1000mm/sec,

Contraction period = 30mm = (30/1000) = 30 msec. 

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1000/30 = 33Hz.

Tetanization- The features of muscle contraction can be demonstrated by eliciting single muscle twitches. The adding together of individual twitch contractions to increase the intensity of overall muscle contraction is Summation. Summation occurs in two ways:

  • by increasing the number of motor units contracting simultaneously, which is multiple ﬁber summations.
  • by increasing the frequency of contraction, which is called frequency summation and can lead to tetanization.

When the frequency of a contraction reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous, this is called tetanization. 

Tetanization occurs in two ways:

  • Complete tetanus occurs when no relaxation occurs between stimuli.
  • Incomplete tetanus when periods of incomplete relaxation take place between the summated stimuli.

questions.text: A target group is being tested by three screening tests for breast cancer as a part of a research program. The patient is considered diseased if she tests positive in all of the screening tests. Which of the following is false about this combination of screening tests?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario where the patient is considered diseased only if she is positive on all three tests, the combination of screening tests is said to be in series. The false statement is that it has high sensitivity. The net sensitivity is low for a screening test conducted in series.

The combination of two or more tests performed together can help to enhance the efficacy of detecting the presence or absence of disease. There are two principal forms of combination of tests:

Screening tests used in series:

  • If a patient is considered to have a disease when he is positive by every test conducted, then the tests are said to be in series.
  • If the patient tests negative in any one or more of the tests, they are classified as non-diseased.
  • It is thus difficult to classify a patient as diseased and easier to classify a patient as non-diseased.
  • With a decrease in sensitivity, there is an increase in the number of false negatives. This higher number of false negatives lowers the sensitivity.

Screening tests used in parallel:

  • If a patient is considered to have a disease when he is positive by any one or more tests, then the tests are said to be in parallel.  
  • Only if the patient tests negative on all the tests, they are classified as non-diseased.
  • Hence, some without disease are more likely to be wrongly classified into the diseased group, but many without disease are correctly excluded.

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby was examined in a village camp. The child had a poor appetite and visible peripheral edema. The hair was sparse and easily pluckable. The skin showed peeling as shown below.  What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette of a child with poor appetite, sparse easily pluckable hair, and the image showing flaky paint dermatosis are suggestive of Kwashiorkar.

Kwashiorkor results due to severe protein and essential amino acid deprivation along with adequate calorie intake. It is particularly seen in children at the time of weaning, to a diet consisting majorly of corn, rice, or beans. 

The clinical features include a classic cutaneous finding of diffuse reddish-brown scaling dermatosis that has been likened to cracked skin, peeling paint, enamel paint, flaky paint, or crazy paving. This is due to the typical scaling and irregular fissuring. Nails are thin and soft. Hairs are thin and sparse and display a flag sign consisting of alternative light and dark bands of hair. The consistent feature is peripheral edema due to the associated hypoproteinaemia. Edema of the face results in moon facies. Abdominal distention (pot belly) is a feature and is due to hepatomegaly from increased fatty deposition due to a lack of available apolipoproteins.

Other options:

Option A: Marasmus results due to global macro-nutrient deficiency, which leads to growth retardation with <60% of ideal body weight. Loss of subcutaneous tissue, growth stunting, dyspigmentation, and desquamative changes are seen in these patients. Marasmus patients do not demonstrate hypoproteinaemia or edema. There is distension of the abdomen due to hypotonia of the abdominal musculature. These patients typically have wrinkled, loose, and dry skin. The hair and nails often grow slowly and may show brittleness. The hair falls out easily and often shows features of alopecia.

Below is the image of a child with marasmus.

Option B: Pellagra results from a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3). It is characterized by the classic presentation of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Casal's necklace is a lesion seen around the neck, which is a characteristic feature seen in pellagra.

Below is the image showing Casal's necklace.

Option C: Vitamin A deficiency can result in phrynoderma that is characterized by keratotic follicular papules along the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral arms. It is seen in the deficiency of vitamin B complex, C, E, and essential fatty acids as well.

questions.text: A middle-aged farmer, presented with fever, chills, and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. The smear prepared from the discharge was stained with Wayson stain and the finding is given below. Which bioterrorism category does the causative organism belong to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, chills, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and a smear showing a characteristic safety pin appearance on Wayson stain is suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis. It belongs to category A bioterrorism.

Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus. The reservoirs of infection are wild rodents like field mice, gerbils, skunks, etc. The important vector of plague is rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis). Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague. 

Investigations include the demonstration of bacillus from the samples of blood, sputum, and buboes. Yersinia is a coccobacillus that exhibits bipolar staining with Wayson's stain. Culture and serology can also be done. Streptomycin is the drug of choice to treat plague, and it should be given intramuscularly in two doses (30 mg/kg). Other preventive measures include regular usage of rodenticides, proper application of effective insecticides, and disinfection. If a patient is suspected to have symptoms suggestive of plague, isolation is advised.

questions.text: During a mitochondrial respiration experiment, malate/pyruvate and succinate both lead to normal respiration. However, when another substance is added in the presence of pyruvate, succinate, and malate, respiration is inhibited. What is the most likely substance that was added?
questions.solution:
In the experiment conducted on mitochondrial respiration, respiration will be blocked by the addition of oligomycin, an antibiotic, when added in the presence of pyruvate/ succinate and malate. Oligomycin inhibits oxidative phosphorylation in the mitochondria and hence blocks respiration.

Electron transport chain (ETC)/respiratory chain is the final pathway by which all the electrons derived from the oxidation of carbohydrates, fatty acids, and amino acids are directed towards the final reaction with oxygen, to form water and adenosine triphosphate (ATP)

In the given experiment, malate and pyruvate are electron donors (NADH) at complex I of the ETC, and succinate is the electron donor (FADH2) at complex II. Normal respiration is observed on the addition of substances at both complexes I and II i.e., both oxygen consumption and ATP synthesis from ADP (adenosine diphosphate) take place.

Oligomycin is a competitive inhibitor of the Fo (oligomycin-sensitive) complex of ATP synthase (complex V) and blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by stopping the flow of protons through the ATP synthase enzyme complex. Hence the addition of oligomycin will inhibit complex V and stop respiration.

Other options :

Option a : Atractyloside inhibits oxidative phosphorylation by inhibiting the transport of ADP into and ATP out of the mitochondria.

Option c : BAL(British anti-lewisite) used as an antidote for arsenic poisoning blocks complex III of the electron transport chain.

Option d : Rotenone if added, will inhibit complex I. Electron transfer before complex I will be blocked but not after. Hence, normal respiration will occur.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with a history of impaired vision and extreme sensitivity to light. Upon examination, the child has light-colored hair, pale skin, and blue eyes. Which enzyme deficiency is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical presentation of a 10-year-old child with impaired vision, heightened light sensitivity, light-colored hair, fair skin, and blue eyes is indicative of albinism, likely due to a deficiency in the enzyme tyrosinase.

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes leading to hypopigmentation. It is either due to defective melanosomes or defective protein involved in the formation and transfer of melanin.

There are 7 types of nonsyndromic albinism (OCA1 to OCA7). OCA type 1 is characterised by reduced or absent tyrosinase activity. The first step in melanin synthesis involves the oxidation of L-tyrosine to DOPA by the enzyme tyrosinase. Tyrosinase further acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which undergoes a series of reactions to form melanin. 

Clinical features include white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-grey in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. Sun protection and corrective lenses are a general line of management. Surgery for strabismus and dark glasses for photophobia are also important.

questions.text: An anxious mother is worried about feeding her baby. The baby was born at 29 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg. What will you advise as a routine primary feeding method for this baby?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a baby born at 29 weeks of gestation and 2 kg birth weight, nasogastric tube feeding can be advised as a routine primary feeding method.

The feeding of neonates depends on their gestational age and it depends on the level of maturity of the neonate. In this scenario, as the baby is 2 kg (low birth weight) and was born at 29 weeks of gestation, nasogastric tube feeding is preferred. Babies born before 32 weeks will not have the coordination between swallowing and breathing. So, paladai feeding can only be used occasionally. Babies born after 34 weeks will have a completely mature sucking pattern and breastfeeding is more preferred.

Based on birth weight, babies can be classified into

  • Low birth weight (LBW) - Birth weight < 2.5kg
  • Very low birth weight (VLBW)- Birth weight <1.5kg
  • Extremely low birth weight (ELBW)- Birth weight <1kg

All LBW infants, irrespective of their initial feeding method should receive only breast milk. This can be given as expressed breast milk (mothers' own milk) to those infants fed by paladai or gastric tube. An alternative is human donor milk. When there is a contraindication to breastfeeding or if the mother is sick, formula feeds can be given. Term formula feed in babies with birth weight >1500 g and preterm formula feed in VLBW babies can be given. All hemodynamically stable LBW babies should receive Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC).

LBW can result from preterm birth (born before 37 completed weeks) IUGR (intrauterine growth restriction) or both. Prematurity and low birth weight are the leading causes of neonatal mortality.

questions.text: A cyanotic baby at the 8th hour of life is being evaluated in NICU. Pulse oximetry shows 80 % not improving with 100 % O2. Records show that continuous machinery murmur was heard at birth but not anymore. Which of the following can be done?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a neonate with a continuous machinery-like murmur and pulse oximetry readings of 80% that do not improve even with 100% oxygen supplementation. This suggests a congenital heart defect that affects oxygenation, specifically Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), which is a cyanotic congenital heart disease. Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) infusion prevents the closure of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in term neonates with underlying cyanotic congenital heart disease awaiting surgical intervention.

In cases where PDA is contributing to cyanotic congenital heart disease, maintaining ductal patency may be necessary to ensure adequate blood flow, particularly to the lungs or systemic circulation. Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) is used in these cases to prevent the closure of the ductus arteriosus, maintaining this crucial blood flow. The goal of PGE1 infusion is to keep the ductus open until further surgical or interventional management can correct the underlying heart defect.Therefore, Prostaglandin E1 infusion is an essential part of managing term neonates with significant PDA, ensuring adequate circulation while preventing further hypoxia and complications.
 

Other options: 

Option a : As the question already mentions the condition is not improving with 100% oxygen, option a can be ruled out.

Option c : Indomethacin is a NSAIDs indicated for closing the ductus arteriosus in premature infants and neonates. 

Option d : PGI2, Epoprostenol improves symptoms and delays the need for lung or heart-lung transplantation in pulmonary artery hypertension.

questions.text:
Arrange the following events in the sequence in which they occur, after 'p wave' in ECG:
1 - a wave in JVP
2 - First heart sound
3 - Rapid filling of ventricles
4 - T wave in ECG
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events that occur after the p-wave is 1-2-4-3

The sequence of the events in this question can be better understood with the following diagram:

  • The p wave in the ECG represents atrial depolarization, which causes contraction of the atria, represented by the 'a' wave in the JVP.
  • Atrial contraction is followed by the closure of the mitral valve, which causes the first-heart sound.
  • This is followed by the isovolumetric contraction of the ventricle, which causes c wave in JVP, due to bulging of the tricuspid valve. This is followed by the rapid ejection phase of the ventricle.
  • The T wave of ECG occurs during ventricular repolarization, which is followed by the opening of the mitral valve, followed by rapid filling phase of the ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is least likely to be injured during an emergency mid-line tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
The structure that is not damaged during an emergency tracheostomy is the inferior thyroid artery, as it is not a mid-line structure. Inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk of the subclavian artery.

Isthumus, arteria thyroid ima, inferior thyroid vein are in the midline and are prone to damage during tracheostomy.

questions.text: The following is a histopathological image of thyroid pathology. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, which are findings suggestive of medullary carcinoma of thyroid.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MTC) arises from the parafollicular C cells. Most of the MTC are sporadic, but they may also be associated with inheritable syndromes like familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B. All the inherited variants are secondary to RET gene mutations.

Most patients present at 50–60 years and have a female preponderance. MTC secretes calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), prostaglandins E2 and F2α, histaminase, serotonin, and adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH).

Features of MTC

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia, or dyspnea if there is local invasion
  • Diarrhea due to increased intestinal motility
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Blood-borne metastasis 
  • Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid stroma

Diagnosis is by careful family history, physical examination, raised calcitonin and CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass.

Other options:

Option B: The image below shows Orphan Annie-eye nuclei with central clearing and margination of chromatin in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Option C: Follicular carcinoma thyroid on histopathology may show uniform cells forming small follicles containing colloid (resembling normal thyroid gland) or sheets of cells without colloid.

Option D: Anaplastic carcinomas are poorly differentiated thyroid carcinomas with varied morphology, including giant cells or spindle-shaped cells or both. There is minimal follicular differentiation with intratumoral necrosis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female, who is known case of DVT is on warfarin therapy from a long-duration. Which of the following clotting factor level may not be affected by warfarin therapy?

DVT - Deep venous thrombosis
questions.solution:
Warfarin, which is an oral anticoagulant drug inhibits Gamma carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, X, but not factor VIII.

Warfarin will inhibit Vitamin K epoxide reductase, an enzyme required for the reduction of vitamin K. Reduced vitamin K is involved in the post-translational modification of blood clotting factors such as

  • prothrombin (factor II)
  • factor VII, factor IX
  • factor X
  • protein C and
  • protein S.

Therefore, warfarin indirectly inhibits the gamma-carboxylation reaction or post-translational modification of blood clotting factors.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding neutrophil extracellular trapping (NET) except that

choices.text: It is detected in blood during sepsis.
It is produced in response to bacterial infection.
It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes.

questions.solution:
Mitochondrial DNA is not seen in neutrophil extracellular traps (NET).

Neutrophilic extracellular traps are networks of extracellular fibers that provide a high concentration of antimicrobial substances at the site of infection and prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils.

Neutrophilic extracellular traps (NET) are the meshwork of nuclear chromatin of neutrophils. The loss of nuclei leads to the death of the neutrophils. They concentrate on antimicrobial peptides and enzymes to fight against bacteria and fungi (not viruses) (option D). They are detected in the blood during sepsis (option A). They are produced by neutrophils in response to:

  • Infectious pathogens: mainly bacteria and fungi (option B).
  • Inflammatory mediators: chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

Note: The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, which includes histones and associated DNA, has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: A 30 yr old male presents with recurrent attacks of sweating and dizziness. Further workup reveals low blood glucose levels with inappropriately elevated insulin and C-peptide levels. Imaging shows a lesion in the pancreas. He is diagnosed with insulinoma and given diazoxide. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Opening of the ATP Sensitive K+ channels
Closing of the ATP Sensitive K+ channels
Increase in number of GLUT-4 receptors
Opening of the voltage sensitive Ca2+ channels

questions.solution:
Diazoxide acts by opening ATP sensitive K+ channels and causing a decrease in insulin secretion. 

Glucose enters beta cells of the pancreas via GLUT-2 receptors. Once inside, it is phosphorylated by glucokinase (rate-limiting step) to glucoe-6-phosphate which is oxidized to form adenosine triphosphate (ATP). This ATP causes closure of ATP-sensitive potassium channels and hence depolarization. This leads to opening voltage-gated calcium channels and Ca2+ influx. This stimulates fusion of the insulin-containing vesicles with the cell membrane and secretion of insulin into the extracellular fluid by exocytosis. 

Diazoxide keeps the ATP sensitive K+ channels open, and prevents depolarization and subsequent insulin release. 

Sulfonylureas cause closure of the ATP snesitive K+ channels, leading to an increased insulin secretion.

questions.text:
Match the curves in the given graph with the changes occurring after death.
  1. Lividity
  2. Rigor
  3. Cooling
  4. Decomposition
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-C, 2-B, 3-A, 4-D.

The graph with the changes occurring after death plotted against time is as follows:

Algor mortis/postmortem cooling is one of the early changes occurring after death. After death, the body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection. Up to the first hour, a temperature plateau may be seen due to the heat generated by residual metabolic activities of dying tissues. This is followed by a linear rate of cooling over the next 12 to 16 hours. The temperature rarely reaches the ambient temperature, most likely due to bacterial action with decomposition setting in. The curve is sigmoid or inverted S-shaped. 

Rigor mortis/cadaveric rigidity/death stiffening refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. It begins 1 to 2 hours after death and lasts for 24 to 48 hours in total. It starts disappearing after 12 hours.

Postmortem lividity/livor mortis develops in the dependent portions of the body due to engorged vessels showing through the skin. It develops shortly after death and may not be visible for up to 1 hour. It deepens in intensity between 1 to 4 hours and reaches a maximum by 6 to 12 hours. Lividity persists until putrefaction sets in.

Decomposition or putrefaction refers to the disintegration of the body tissues after death. Multiplication of the bacteria begins within 4 hours after death and by 18 to 36 hours gases collect in the body causing bloating and distortion. The body then undergoes putrefaction and liquefaction of the tissues 5 to 10 days after death.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone acts via this pathway?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, which is associated with tyrosine kinase receptors. Among the given hormones leptin acts via this pathway.

Hormones that use receptor tyrosine kinase/ JAK-STAT signaling include the following:

  • Growth hormone
  • Fibroblast growth factor
  • Hepatocyte growth factor
  • Insulin
  • Insulin-like growth factor-1
  • Leptin
  • Prolactin
  • Vascular endothelial growth factor

Leptin is a hormone that is secreted by fat cells. The physiological effects of leptin are regulating appetite and energy balance. The leptin receptor acts via tyrosine kinase of the Janus kinase (JAK) family, JAK2. Leptin binds to the extracellular part of the leptin receptor, which causes phosphorylation (P) and activation of the intracellular JAK2. This causes phosphorylation of signal transducer and activation of transcription (STAT) proteins, which results in the transcription of target genes and the synthesis of proteins.

Phosphorylation of JAK2 also results in the activation of other intracellular enzyme pathways such as mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPK) and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K).

Other options:

Hormones such as adrenal (Aldosterone)and gonadal steroid hormones, thyroid hormones, retinoid hormones, and vitamin D, bind with protein receptors inside the cell rather than on the cell surface. These hormones are lipid soluble and they readily cross the cell membrane and interact with receptors in the cytoplasm or nucleus.

Vasopressin in the epithelial cells acts via V2 receptor. They use adenylyl cyclase as their second messenger system. Vasopressin in the vascular smooth muscles acts via V1 receptor that uses phospholipase C as the second messenger system.

HAART- Highly active anti retroviral therapy

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of adverse effects of efavirenz. It acts at site 4, i.e it inhibits HIV reverse transcriptase.

Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). It is effective against HIV-1 only.

The adverse effects of efavirenz are mainly neuropsychiatric. These include dizziness, impaired concentration, dysphoria, disturbing or vivid dreams, and insomnia. However, these symptoms resolve within the first 4 weeks of therapy and are tolerable.

Other side effects include skin rash, headache, increased hepatic transaminases, and elevated serum cholesterol.

questions.text: A teacher complains that a 7-year-old girl with falling grades is inattentive in class and has unresponsive episodes with staring. On hyperventilation, her symptoms increase and her EEG findings show a 3Hz spike and wave discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child who is inattentive in class and has unresponsive episodes with staring with EEG showing a 3Hz spike and wave discharge is suggestive of typical absence seizures.

Absence seizures are a form of generalized seizures marked by unresponsiveness, staring, and eye flutter which usually last for a few seconds. GABAB receptors, T-type Ca2+ channels, and K+ channels situated within the thalamus are involved in the pathophysiology of absence seizures.

It is of two types:

  • Typical absence seizures  
  • Atypical absence seizures  

Typical absence seizures are associated with 3-Hz spikes and slow wave discharges on EEG. It usually starts by the age of 5-8 years and can occur up to a hundred times per day. Hyperventilation can precipitate seizures and EEG changes. They last only for a few seconds and do not have an aura. It can be accompanied by eyelid flutter or upward rolling of the eyes. Simple automatisms such as lip smacking or picking at clothing can also be seen. There is no postictal period and the child usually resumes whatever activity he/she was engaged in prior to the episode. 

Atypical absence seizures are associated with 1-2-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges. Head atonia and myoclonus can also be seen during the seizures. It is precipitated by drowsiness and is generally more difficult to treat. 

Juvenile absence seizures occur at a later stage and are similar to typical absences. It is marked by 4-to-6 Hz spike-and-slow-wave and polyspike-and-slow-wave discharges. It is associated with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

EEG is the diagnostic test for absence seizures. An MRI would appear normal and so is not useful. Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for typical absence seizures. Its mechanism of action is the inhibition of T-type calcium channels. Phenytoin, carbamazepine, and oxcarbazepine have all been associated with aggravation of absence seizures and even absence status epilepticus in children with absence epilepsy.

The following epilepsy syndromes are associated with the absence seizures:

  • Childhood absence epilepsy
  • Juvenile absence epilepsy
  • Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy
  • Myoclonic absence epilepsy
  • Lennox-gestaut syndrome

Other options:

Option A: Myoclonic seizures can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. It is marked by the rapidity of jerks (<50 mseconds). EEG changes depend on the type of myoclonic seizure.

Option B: Myoclonus is very brief, abrupt, and involuntary jerky contractions of a single muscle or muscle group. Some causes of myoclonus in children include hiccups (physiologic), meningitis, and electrolyte disturbances.  

Option D: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy also known as Janz syndrome is a type of generalized epilepsy seen in young adults. It presents as myoclonic jerks in the morning and generalized tonic-clonic or clonic-tonic-clonic seizures upon awakening. Sleep deprivation and photic stimulation can precipitate the episodes. 4-5 Hz polyspike-and-slow-wave discharges can be seen on EEG.

questions.text: While working as a resident in a hospital, you are asked by the consultant to prescribe a certain proton-pump inhibitor (PPI). It should be given only orally once daily before breakfast, even though it has a half-life of no more than 3 hours. What is the rationale behind this once-daily dosing?

choices.text: The drug can inhibit all gastric pumps.
The drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.
The drug is gradually released irrespective of its formulation.
The drug suppresses basal but not stimulated acid production.

questions.solution:
The rationale behind the once-daily dosing is that the drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.

Proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs) are prodrugs that are activated only after undergoing an acid-catalyzed cleavage in the canaliculi of the parietal cells of the stomach.

On administration, they are absorbed in the proximal small bowel and eventually, block the H+/K+ ATPase enzyme, the "proton pump" in the parietal cells of the stomach. The secretion of protons by an activated H+/K+- ATPase (proton pump) in the parietal cells into the gastric lumen is the final step involved in the production of gastric acid and inhibition of this enzyme prevents acid secretion into the stomach.

Once PPIs irreversibly inactivate the H+K+-ATPase pump, acid secretion resumes only after new pump molecules are synthesized and inserted into the luminal membrane. This leads to prolonged suppression of acid secretion for up to 24-48 hours, despite having a shorter plasma half-life of only 30 minutes to 3 hours.

In most individuals, once-daily dosing is enough to achieve effective acid inhibition. If necessary, a second dose can be given before an evening meal.

The number of H+K+-ATPase pump molecules increases after fasting and food decreases the oral bioavailability of the drug. Hence, PPIs are given around 30 minutes before the first meal of the day.

Other options :

Option a : PPIs cannot inhibit all gastric acid pumps with oral dosing because not all pumps are active during the short half-life of the PPI in the blood. 

Option c : There are available in the form of delayed-release tablets, capsules, and oral suspension packets and for immediate acid suppression, there are intravenous formulations for PPIs like lansoprazole, pantoprazole, and esomeprazole. Therefore, the release of the drug depends upon the drug formulation.

Option d : PPIs cause maximum suppression of gastric acid. They reduce the daily production of both basal and stimulated acid secretion by 85–90%.

questions.text: A 29 year old female came to hospital with complaints of burning sensation in vagina and vaginal discharge since last 40 days. She also complains of increase in urine frequency since past 5 days. On per vaginal examination, greenish frothy discharge is seen and per speculum examination findings are shown below. Which of the following treatment kits would you recommend for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing strawberry cervix are suggestive of Trichomoniasis. The green kit containing Tablet Secnidazole 2 gm, to be taken orally as a single dose is recommended in its treatment.

Trichomoniasis is the infection of the female genital tract with the Trichomonas vaginalis protozoan. It characteristically causes a copious, frothy, offensive yellow-green discharge with vaginal soreness or irritation and urinary frequency. The vagina looks red and inflamed like a strawberry with punctate hemorrhagic spots.

Management: The CDC recommends one of the following treatment regimens.

  • Metronidazole 2 g orally in a single dose or Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose
  • The alternative regimen includes Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice a day for 7 days
  • Metronidazole gel does not reach therapeutic levels in the urethra and perivaginal glands. It is not recommended as it is less efficacious than oral metronidazole.

Other options:

Option a : The red kit is used in herpetic genital ulcer disease, in which the treatment of asymptomatic partners is not required.

Option b : The blue kit is used in non-herpetic genital ulcer disease when the patient is allergic to penicillin. All partners in the last 3 months should be treated.

Option d :  The grey kit is used in men for urethral discharge and scrotal swelling. All recent partners should be treated. However, when used for cervical discharge in women, only symptomatic male partners need to be treated.

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette in a patient with paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve.

Injury to the saphenous nerve is common following venous cut down for access to the great saphenous vein, in this case for coronary bypass graft.

Saphenous nerve:

It is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body. It arises from the posterior division of the femoral nerve. It then enters the adductor canal and exits it by piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius and supplies the skin over the patella. The saphenous nerve then descends along the medial border of the tibia along with the great saphenous vein (anterior to the vein) and supplies the skin on the medial side of the knee, leg, and foot as far as up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.

Saphenous nerve injury:

When the great saphenous vein is being harvested for coronary bypass graft, injury to the saphenous nerve is common as it closely travels with the great saphenous vein. Sensory loss over the medial side of the knee, leg, and foot is observed in saphenous nerve injury. 

Other options: 

Option A: Superficial peroneal nerve injury causes sensory loss over the lateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot.

Option C: Femoral nerve gives rise to anterior cutaneous branches, the saphenous nerve, and motor supply to the quadriceps and sartorius. Anterior cutaneous branches supply the skin on the anterior thigh and knee. If the saphenous nerve was not an option in the question, the femoral nerve would have been the next best answer. 

Option D: Sural nerve injury causes sensory loss over the posterior and lateral aspects of the distal third of the leg and lateral side of the foot and fifth toe. It is often used as an autologous peripheral nerve graft as it is readily identified and easy to harvest.

questions.text: A silver-stained section of the cerebral cortex shows numerous cells of the type shown below. Which of the following cells could they most likely be?
questions.solution:
Since the silver-stained section of the cerebral cortex shows a triangular cell with a broad base, it is likely to be a pyramidal cell.

Pyramidal cells have a triangular shape, with a broad base from which a single axon and many basilar dendrites emerge. A single apical trunk usually projects from the apex. The apices of these cells orient towards the pial surface of the cortex.

Pyramidal cells of Betz are larger pyramidal cells seen in the precentral gyrus. They measure up to 120 μm.

Pyramidal cells are the most abundant type of cortical neurons. Their fibers give rise to the corticospinal tract. 

Nerve cells present in the cerebral cortex include:

  • Pyramidal cells
  • Stellate cells or granule cells
  • Fusiform cells
  • Horizontal cells of Cajal
  • Cells of Martinotti

Other options:

Options A and B: Purkinje cells and Golgi cells are found in the cerebellum. Purkinje cells have flask-shaped cell bodies with axons containing efferent fibers of the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells are large, stellate cells lying in the granular layer of the cerebellum with dendrites that branch extensively and are located deep in the Purkinje cells. 

Option D: Glomus cells are neuroendocrine cells found in the carotid body. Like neurons, they too have dendritic processes and cytoplasm containing numerous membrane-bound granules.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar Circuitary

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

  • Climbing fibers -
    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle
    • Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: Dystrophin protein is absent completely in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Dystrophin protein (a sarcolemmal protein), is absent in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) due to a mutation in the dystrophin gene. Lack of dystrophin leads to cellular instability, which leads to progressive leakage of intracellular components.

Dystrophin connects actin filaments to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan in the sarcolemma by the smaller proteins syntrophins in the cytoplasm.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. It is an X-linked recessive disorder, and the causative gene is located at Xp21.

  • Clinical features: Progressive weakness with developmental delay occurs. Pseudohypertrophy of calves and wasting of thigh muscles are seen. Trendelenburg gait or hip waddle is characteristic.
    Gower’s sign: Indicates weakness of proximal muscles: The patient has to use hands and arms to "walk up" their own body from a squatting position.
  • Diagnosis: Elevated serum creatine kinase levels. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis for the dystrophin gene. If PCR is normal, but clinical suspicion is high, muscle biopsy with dystrophin immunocytochemistry is done.
  • Treatment: Treatment of cardiac decompensation, nutritional management, physiotherapy, and glucocorticoids.
  • Prognosis: Death occurs usually at about 18 to 20 years of age due to respiratory failure, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or aspiration.

Other options:

Option A: Becker's muscular dystrophy(BMD) leads to abnormal dystrophin formation, whereas the dystrophin gene mutation in DMD leads to dystrophin deficiency.

Option C: Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles, due to a decrease in the number of available acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at neuromuscular junctions as a result of antibody-mediated autoimmune attack.

Option D: Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome is a neuromuscular junction disorder associated with the reduced acetylcholine (Ach) release from the presynaptic nerve terminals, despite normal ACh vesicle numbers, ACh presynaptic concentration, and postsynaptic ACh receptors.

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.solution:
HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis is defined as inflammation of brain parenchyma caused by the herpes virus, and it typically presents as an acute febrile illness.

Patients typically present with acute onset of fever, altered levels of consciousness, personality changes, and evidence of either focal or diffuse neurologic signs and symptoms, especially in the temporal lobe. Focal or generalized seizures occur in many patients with HSV encephalitis. Other most commonly encountered focal findings include aphasia, ataxia, upper motor neuron or lower motor neuron type lesions, and cranial nerve deficits.

HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. Other investigations that can help include CSF examination, CSF culture, serological studies, MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy.

The T2-weighted MRI of the brain will show hyperintensity in the temporal lobe in most of the patients. Bilateral involvement of the temporal lobe is more common in HSV encephalitis.

The image below is a coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes in a patient with HSV encephalitis.

Management includes supportive therapy (monitoring of intracranial pressure, fluid restriction, avoidance of hypotonic IV fluids), anticonvulsants for seizures, and intravenous acyclovir is beneficial in the treatment of HSV encephalitis.

 Other options:

Option A: IgM antibodies in CSF - Serological tests to detect antibodies are used for primary herpes infections.

Option B: Tzanck smear of CSF - A positive smear shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and ground glass appearance. It is a rapid, inexpensive, and fairly sensitive diagnostic test. The Tzanck smear is typically used to diagnose cutaneous herpes infections, such as herpes simplex or varicella-zoster virus. It is not an appropriate diagnostic test for HSV encephalitis, as it does not provide definitive confirmation of the presence of HSV in the CSF.

Option D: CSF culture in chick embryos - It is not a sensitive test used for the diagnosis of HSV encephalitis. Negative CSF viral cultures have no value in ruling out HSV encephalitis. Although this method can be used to isolate HSV, it is not as sensitive or specific as PCR for viral DNA and it can take a longer time to obtain results.

questions.text: During the examination of a 10-year-boy patient, signs suggesting potential abuse were noted. A sample from the perianal region was taken and tested with potassium iodide, resulting in the formation of dark brown rhombic, needle-shaped crystals. What test was performed?
questions.solution:
The test performed in this scenario is the Florence test, which is utilized to identify the presence of seminal fluid in suspected cases of sexual abuse.

Florence test detects choline which is secreted by seminal vesicles. The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide. A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip. If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately. The test is not confirmatory for the presence of semen, however, a negative reaction rules out the presence of semen.

Other options:

Option A: Barberio test is used to detect the presence of seminal fluid. The stain used is saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid. If semen is present, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Option C: Paraffin test is used to detect gunpowder residue (nitrate and nitrites). 

Option D: Kastle Meyer test is used to detect the presence of bloodstain. A positive Kastle Meyer's (phenolphthalein) test is suggestive of a bloodstain.
This test is done by adding phenolphthalein reagent and hydrogen peroxide to the extracted stain sample. Pink or purple colour indicates a positive test.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms can cause duodenal ulcers?
questions.solution:
Among the given options Helicobacter pylori can cause duodenal ulcers.

H. pylori is a gram-negative motile rod with lophotrichous flagella. It has a unique feature of the production of urease, which is helpful in diagnosis. The sole source of H. pylori is the human gastric mucus. The gastric antrum is the most common site of colonization. 

In some patients, H. pylori causes mild acute gastritis lasting for about two weeks. In others, it can cause peptic ulcer disease, duodenal ulcers, and in later stages may lead to chronic atrophic gastritis. This is a risk factor for gastric malignancies like adenocarcinoma and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphomas. 

Diagnosis can be made by performing a biopsy. A piece of biopsy material is added to a urease indicator medium which will show a positive result within minutes inside the endoscopy room. Part of the biopsy material is sent for microscopy and culture. On microscopy, Warthin-Starry silver staining can be done where spiral bacilli are seen, as shown below.

The standard treatment is a combination of bismuth subsalicylate, tetracycline, and metronidazole for 2 weeks. Alternatively, proton pump inhibitors like omeprazole are also used along with clarithromycin. Treatment is not given for asymptomatic patients.

Other options:

Option A: Shigella dysenteriae causes bacillary dysentery which is characterized by fever and generalized abdominal tenderness.

Option B: Vibrio parahaemolyticus grows only in media that contain sodium chloride. It can tolerate salt concentrations of up to 8% in the media. The most commonly used media for this is thiosulphate citrate bile salts sucrose agar (TCBS). This organism is known to cause food poisoning associated with seafood. 

Option D: Lactobacilli is a gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic, non-motile, non–spore-forming bacterium. Lactobacillus derives lactic acid from glucose, creating an acidic environment, and thus can grow in an acidic medium. It is found in the vagina as part of its normal microbiota.

questions.text: Hering-Breuer reflexes are mediated by ______
questions.solution:
Hering-Breuer reflexes are mediated by slowly adapting pulmonary stretch receptors and the impulses travel in the vagus nerve via large myelinated fibers.

Hering-Breuer inflation reflex means prolonged inspiration inhibits further inspiration. Overinflation of the lung activates the pulmonary stretch receptors. Signals from these receptors travel through the vagus nerve and inhibit the inspiratory ramp signals in dorsal respiratory group of neurons. This also increases the respiratory rate. It is a protective mechanism and prevents over inflation of the lungs.

Advantages of Hering-Breuer inflation reflex is, it cuts down the inspiration time, and therefore, It prevents overinflation of the lungs. Lungs operate at lower lung volumes, thereby preventing wastage of energy. The Hering-Breuer reflex is activated when the lung volume increases to more than three times the normal tidal volume (tidal volume = 0.5 liters/breath; So, lung volume > 1.5 liters per breath activates the reflex). It signifies that the reflex play a protetive role preventing the overinflation of the lung rather than regulating the normal ventilation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old farmer came to the outpatient department (OPD) with complaints of gradually worsening weakness in his legs. Initially, he could walk with short, jerky steps without assistance, but over time, his gait became crossed, and he now requires sticks for balance. What is the cofactor of the enzyme inhibited by this toxin?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points towards lathyrism caused due to BOAA (beta oxalyly amino alanine). This toxin inhibits the enzyme lysyl oxidase whose cofactor is copper.

Lysyl oxidase is a copper-containing enzyme that is involved in the formation of cross-links in collagen synthesis. Inhibition of the enzyme by the sweat pea toxin leads to defective collagen formation and leads to lathyrism.  

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus or its variants such as sweet pea(Lathyrus odoratus). It is mostly consumed by agricultural laborers of poor economic status because it is relatively cheap. It can present as skeletal, vascular, or neural manifestations.

It usually affects young males aged 15-45 years and it is manifested in stages: 

  • Latent stage
  • No-stick stage
  • One-stick stage
  • Two-stick stage
  • Crawler stage

The patient is initially able to walk with short jerky steps without any aids, but the progressive spastic paralysis causes a crossed gait, and the patient has to use sticks to maintain his balance. Eventually, the knee joints are unable to support the weight of the body and the patient cannot stand erect at all. Long-term consumption of khesari dal leads to neurolathyrism. It is characterized by gradual spastic paralysis of the lower limbs.

The interventions that can be used to prevent lathyrism include:

  • Vitamin C prophylaxis
  • Limiting the proportion of the dal to less than a quarter of the total cereals and pulses consumed in a day
  • Removal of the toxin by parboiling and steeping method.
