questions.text: Which of the following side effects are seen most commonly with Isotretinoin (13-cis-retinoic acid)?
questions.solution:
Embryopathy is the most common side effect seen with isotretinoin.

Isotretinoin is a vitamin A derivative that is highly teratogenic when orally administered. It is commonly used to treat cystic nodular acne. It inhibits the migration of neural crest cells during embryogenesis and affects the development of multiple organs. These defects are collectively termed retinoic acid embryopathy.

Specific anomalies may include ventriculomegaly, maldevelopment of the facial bones or cranium, microtia or anotia, micrognathia, cleft palate, conotruncal heart defects, and thymic aplasia or hypoplasia.

Isotretinoin also increases the risk of spontaneous abortions and stillbirths by up to 40% in pregnancies exposed in the first quarter of this medicine. Presenting with pregnancy during treatment with isotretinoin is a failure of prevention strategies.

The guidelines for isotretinoin usage are as follows:

  • Isotretinoin is a teratogenic drug that should not be taken during pregnancy and nursing
  • Patients should take 2 pregnancy tests before starting isotretinoin and take a monthly pregnancy test while on the medication, and another test 1 month after stopping the medication.
  • Two forms of birth control should be simultaneously used starting 1 month before treatment, during the entire course of treatment, and for 1 month after ceasing treatment with isotretinoin.
  • Isotretinoin should be reserved for the treatment of severe, nodulocystic acne and should not be used for milder forms of acne.

Other options:

Option B: Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorder. It is a teratogen associated with Ebstein's anomaly which is a rare cardiac condition characterized by severe tricuspid regurgitation and right atrial enlargement.

Option C: Valproic acid is the anti-epileptic which confers the greatest risk to the developing fetus while used in pregnancy. It is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Option D: Tetracyclines are associated with yellowish-brown discoloration of deciduous teeth when used after 25 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with hyperpigmented macules on her upper lip, malar regions, forehead, chin, and mandible, which worsen after sun exposure. Based on this clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 30-year-old woman showing hyperpigmented macules on the upper lip, malar regions, forehead, chin, and mandible region is suggestive of melasma.

Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis and is manifested by hyperpigmented macules on the face which become more pronounced after sun exposure. Hyper-melanosis affects mainly the upper lip, the malar regions, the forehead,  chin and the mandible region. It is more common in women (90%) and in ages between 20-40 years. Melasma is frequently seen in women on oral contraceptives. Melasma is more chronic and requires treatment with depigmenting agents like hydroquinone (reduces tyrosinase activity), kojic acid (tyrosinase inhibitor), chemical peels and Kligman's triple combination- topical hydroquinone + tretinoin + corticosteroid compound cream (First line)

Other Options:

Option A: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus: A well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

Option C: The same facial melanosis in pregnant women is called Chloasma or mask of pregnancy. Only the terms used differ. Chloasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Chloasma usually resolves after pregnancy.

Option D: Rosacea is seen at the convexities of the face and presents as an erythemato-telangiectatic type over the cheeks.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby showed signs of hypertonia, irritability, and tonic spasms triggered by light. These symptoms quickly worsened, leading to the baby's death. An autopsy was performed, and a histological examination of the brain tissue was conducted. Which enzyme was deficient in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hypertonia, irritability and tonic spasms with light and the image showing characteristic globoid cells are suggestive of Krabbe disease. The enzyme deficient in Krabbe's disease is beta-galactosidase.

Krabbe's disease or globoid cell leukodystrophy is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin loss and the presence of globoid bodies in white matter.

It is an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy due to the deficiency of galactocerebroside β-galactosidase. β-galactosidase helps in the catabolism of galactocerebroside to ceramide and galactose. As a result, an alternative catabolic pathway shunts galactocerebroside to galactosyl sphingosine. Elevated levels of these compounds are cytotoxic and cause the destruction of oligodendroglia.

The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness. Patients also have irritability and tonic spasms with light or noise stimulation. They often don't survive beyond the age of 2 years. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

The characteristic and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease is the aggregation of engorged macrophages called globoid cells in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels.

Other options:

Option B: A deficiency of enzyme alpha-galactosidase results in Fabry's disease. It is characterized by painful acroparaesthesia, hypohidrosis, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, small petechiae around the umbilicus, lenticular opacities, and corneal dystrophy.

Option C: A deficiency of enzyme beta-glucosidase results in Gaucher's disease. It is characterized by joint pain mostly affecting hips and knees, pancytopenia, convulsions, and hepatosplenomegaly. It shows crumbled tissue paper appearance on microscopy.

Option D: A deficiency in enzyme arylsulphatase A results in metachromatic leukodystrophy. It is characterized by progressive regression of milestones, ataxia dysarthria, hypotonia, spasticity hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and optic atrophy.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy was accidentally shot by a friend while they were experimenting with a gun. The image below shows his gunshot wound. Which of the following characteristics are absent in this wound?

The features seen in the image indicate that this was a close shot, i.e., the distance between the victim and the firing is 5-8cm. The victim is within the range of the flame, hence, features related to flame, smoke, and powder deposition will be seen. Singeing, burning, blackening and tattooing will be present.

In a firm contact shot, the imprint of the muzzle of the gun is seen on the skin around the wound. Wound edge eversion is also seen. The victim is within the range of flame, hence singeing of the hair will be present. Tattooing begins only when the muzzle-to-target distance is >1cm, like in a loose contact shot.

When the distance between the victim and the firing is >50 cm, it is a distant shot. The victim lies outside the range of flame and powder deposition. Hence, features related to flame, smoke, and powder deposition are absent. Burning, blackening, and tattooing are absent.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman from China has an echocardiography report showing dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following conditions could account for her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient is probably suffering from Keshan's disease, which is due to selenium deficiency.

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low. Mainly dilated cardiomyopathy is characteristic, and may also result in cardiomegaly, congestive cardiac failure and fulminant cardiogenic shock. Selenium is an important trace element that is a part of the 21st amino acid selenocysteine.

There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as, Glutathione peroxidase, De-iodinase, Thioredoxin reductase. Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant that complements the role of vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

Clinical correlates:

  • Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low.

  • Selenium toxicity (Kashinbeck Disease): Chronic ingestion of high amounts of selenium leads to selenosis (Kashinbeck disease). It is characterized by hair and nail brittleness, garlic breath odor, myopathy, irritability, and other abnormalities of the nervous system.

Other options :

Option a : Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency leads to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which are characterized by symptoms such as muscle weakness, peripheral neuropathy, cardiovascular issues, and confusion. While cognitive dysfunction can result from thiamine deficiency, rash and loose stools do not fit with thiamine deficiency. Therefore, thiamine would not address the full spectrum of this patient’s symptoms.

Option c : Zinc deficiency causes acrodermatitis enteropathica. It presents after weaning with diarrhea, alopecia, and a cutaneous eruption in the periorificial and acral areas. Children often have symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with crusted edges. It is associated with nutritional alopecia like marasmus and kwashiorkor but flag sign is not seen.

Option d : Copper deficiency leads to anemia, growth retardation, defective keratinization and pigmentation of hair, hypothermia, degenerative changes in aortic elastin, osteopenia and mental retardation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a history of facial edema that has now progressed to total body swelling involving the face, abdomen, scrotum, and feet. Urinalysis revealed protein 4+ and a urine protein: creatinine ratio of 3. What is the initial treatment of choice for this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and investigations are highly suggestive of minimal change nephrotic syndrome and the initial treatment of choice is corticosteroids such as prednisolone.

Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years with a clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome, that is, heavy proteinuria, edema, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. They may be asymptomatic or can present with peripheral edema. Renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the child fits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome.

They show excellent response to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone. A daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks is recommended.

Alternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistant patients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are as follows:

  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Calcineurin inhibitors: Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus
  • Mycophenolate

  • Rituximab (chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD20)

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: The POCSO Act is related to:
questions.solution:
POCSO (The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act is related to Child sexual abuse.

  • The Act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age.
  • It defines different forms of sexual abuse, including penetrative and non-penetrative assault, as well as sexual harassment and pornography, and deems a sexual assault to be “aggravated” under certain circumstances, such as when the abused child is mentally ill or when the abuse is committed by a person in a position of trust or authority vis-à-vis the child, like a family member, police officer, teacher, or doctor.
  • People who traffic children for sexual purposes are also punishable under the provisions relating to abetment in the Act. The Act prescribes stringent punishment graded as per the gravity of the offence, with a maximum term of rigorous imprisonment for life, and fine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the Dose response curve shown in the image below:

choices.text: C is more potent than A
B is more potent than A

questions.solution:
In the above image, Drug B is a Competitive antagonist

In competitive antagonism, the Dose-responce curve (DRC) is shifted to the right whereas in non-competitive antagonism the dose-response curve is flattened.

Thus in the above image Drug B is the Competitive antagonist while Drug C is the non-competitive antagonist.

Potency is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response. A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa. The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. Thus, in the above image, the potency is Drug A > Drug C > Drug B.
 

Efficacy is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug. It expresses the effect produced by the receptors when bound by a certain drug. In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy. Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

questions.text: A newborn presented with chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The pediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to the deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Respiratory distress syndrome in a neonate is likely due to the deficiency of lecithin.

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease, is due to the decreased production and secretion of the lung surfactant. Surfactant is a lipoprotein primarily made of phospholipids such as lecithin (otherwise known as dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine). The other minor components are phosphatidylglycerol, apoproteins, and cholesterol. It is synthesized in type II pneumocytes/granular pneumocytes in the endoplasmic reticulum (shown below). 

RDS is commonly seen in preterm babies less than 34 weeks of gestation. Surfactant deficiency leads to an increase in the surface tension over the alveoli, causing the alveoli to collapse easily during expiration. Therefore, the baby has to put more effort into expanding the lungs. Tachypnea, cyanosis, nasal flaring, prominent expiratory grunting, and intercostal and subcostal retractions are some of the common findings seen in this condition. 

Chest x-ray shows features such as reticulogranular pattern, ground-glass opacity, and air bronchogram. White-out lungs can be seen on chest X-rays in severe diseases.

Management in mild to moderate RDS is with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), where the positive pressure keeps the alveoli open in a spontaneously breathing baby. Severe cases will require mechanical ventilation. Steroids increase the production of the surfactant, and therefore, steroids are administered antenatally to mothers with preterm labor.

Other options:

Option A: Dipalmitoyl inositol, or phosphatidylinositol, acts as a precursor for the secondary messenger system. It also helps in cell signaling and membrane trafficking. 

Option C: Sphingomyelin is a dominant sphingolipid in the plasma membrane. The lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio in amniotic fluid helps in determining fetal lung maturity.

Option D: Dipalmitoyl ethanolamine is present in the cell membrane.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought with bilateral cheek swelling,  pain, tenderness, and fever for the last two days. Which of the following is not a complication of this infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a parotid swelling with fever is suggestive of mumps infection. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is not a complication of this disease. SSPE is caused by a measles infection.

Mumps is an infection caused by the mumps virus, a paramyxovirus. It causes non-suppurative inflammation and growth of the parotid glands. 

The mode of infection is inhalation or contact through the conjunctiva. The virus infects the respiratory tract leading to replication and dissemination through the cervical lymph nodes and bloodstream. The incubation period is about 12-25 days

Mumps infection usually presents with unilateral or bilateral parotid swelling. Unilateral disease usually progresses to bilateral involvement. It is accompanied by fever, local pain and tenderness but the skin over the gland is not warm or erythematous. It is usually self-limiting and resolves within a week. However, the involvement of other organs is detrimental and leads to severe complications.

Complications of mumps infection: 

  1. Epidymo-orchitis (Option A) is characterized by swollen, intensely painful testicles. This is usually associated with fever and chills. This may lead to testicular atrophy and decreased sperm counts. 
  2. Meningoencephalitis (Option B) or meningitis can occur. This is usually aseptic and is characterized by pleocytosis on cerebrospinal fluid examination. This may lead to deafness as a complication. 
  3. Acute pancreatitis (Option C) can occur. This generally resolves with conservative treatment. 
  4. Arthritis may occur with monoarticular or polyarticular involvement. 
  5. Myocardial involvement: Transient ECG changes are seen. Rapidly progressive myocarditis can occur.

A typical case of mumps needs no laboratory confirmation, but in atypical cases and complications, diagnosis may be established by virus isolation and serological tests.

Prophylaxis of mumps is done through the administration of an effective live virus vaccine containing the Jeryl-Lynn strain of the virus. The vaccine is given as a single subcutaneous injection, alone or in combination with the measles and rubella vaccines (Measles - Mumps - Rubella vaccine: MMR vaccine)

questions.text: A 6-year-old fully immunized healthy boy suddenly develops a high fever along with difficulty swallowing. The child is unwilling to lie down and sits with his chin up, and mouth open. Noisy breathing is also noted. Lateral radiographs of the neck demonstrate the finding shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a immunized child with high fever, difficulty swallowing, noisy breathing, and a lateral radiograph showing a thumb sign points towards the diagnosis of acute epiglottitis.

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive inflammation of the epiglottis causing obstructive laryngitis and presents with high fever, severe sore throat, tachycardia, systemic toxicity, and drooling as patients are unable to swallow. The patient characteristically leans forward while sitting for ease of breathing.

The diagnosis is often made bedside. On direct fiberoptic laryngoscopy, the typical edematous cherry-red epiglottis is visualized. Neck radiographs reveal an enlarged edematous epiglottis (Thumb sign). The below image shows the thumb sign.

Treatment includes airway management followed by administration of antibiotics like ampicillin/sulbactam, cefotaxime, or ceftriaxone. 

Other options - 

Option A: Laryngeal diphtheria is unlikely to occur in a fully immunized child, and diphtheria is typically associated with membrane formation. 

Option B: Retropharyngeal abscess is seen secondary to infections and usually does not present with fever. Children usually present with a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, lateral to the midline. It is confirmed by a lateral X-ray of the neck which shows a widening of the prevertebral shadow. 

Option D: Croup is usually gradual in onset and is usually preceded by prodromal symptoms. Also, fever is usually absent in such patients.

questions.text:
Which of the following pedigree charts correspond to the pattern of inheritance that would be seen in the case of G6PD deficiency?

G6PD- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
G-6-PD deficiency has an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance as shown in image 1.

Clues for diagnosis of the pattern of inheritance as X-linked recessive:

  • Males are affected and females are carriers.
  • No male-to-male transmission. Females transmit the disease.
  • Affected males have carrier daughters and unaffected sons.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway. Its deficiency commonly manifests as neonatal jaundice and episodic acute hemolytic anaemia. The common provoking agents are infections, some drugs like sulfa drugs/ quinine group, and fava beans.

MELAS (mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes) follows a mitochondrial inheritance pattern as shown below.

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

 

Autosomal Dominant Disorders:

  • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some patients do not have affected parents. Such patients owe their disorder to new mutations involving either the egg or the sperm from which they were derived.
  • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity.
  • In many conditions, the age at onset is delayed, and symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood (as in Huntington disease).

X-linked Recessive Conditions:

  • All sex-linked disorders are X-linked, and almost all are recessive.
  • Several genes are located in the “male-specific region of Y;” all these are related to spermatogenesis.
  • Males with mutations affecting the Y-linked genes are usually infertile, and hence, there is no Y-linked inheritance.
  • An affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons, but all daughters are carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous women have, of course, a one-in-two chance of receiving the mutant gene.
  • Heterozygous females express the disorder partially because of random inactivation of one X chromosome.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever for 1 week, with abdominal distension, loss of appetite and lymphadenopathy. There is a poor response to antibiotics and antimalarials. The Widal test is negative but  rk39 is positive. Which drug can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient should be managed with liposomal amphotericin B.

This is a case of visceral leishmaniasis, and it presents with fever associated with rigor and chills. Splenomegaly and hepatomegaly are common. Lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic regions, but in the Indian subcontinent, it is rare. 

Diagnosis is by ELISA and the indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT) and rk39 which detects antibodies to Leishmania donovani. 

Medical Therapy :

In most endemic regions (except in India and Mediterranian countries):

  • Pentavalent antimonial is the drug of choice (sodium stibogluconate or meglumine antimoniate)
  • If initial pentavalent antimonial fails, then amphotericin B (AmB) is used.

In India and Mediterranian countries:

  • Liposomal AmB is the drug of choice.

Other drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis include: paromomycin and miltefosine.

Other options:

Option b: Fluconazole is an antifungal and is not useful in visceral leishmaniasis

Option c: Linezolid is used in the treatment of MRSA  and related infections.

Option d: Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used in MDR-TB.

questions.text: A child who has overdosed on iron tablets comes with nausea and abdominal pain. What is the antidote for this toxicity?
questions.solution:
The antidote used for iron overdose is deferoxamine.

Deferoxamine, a potent iron-chelating compound, can be given intravenously to bind iron that has already been absorbed and to promote its excretion in urine and faeces. Hypotension is a common side effect of deferoxamine infusion. The deferoxamine-iron complex can colour the urine reddish.

Iron toxicity presents as profuse vomiting and diarrhoea (often bloody), abdominal pain, and significant volume losses. Later patients develop multisystem organ failure, shock, and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: After collecting data, an epidemiologist observes that the nation’s death rate is falling more quickly than its birth rate. In which stage of the demographic cycle would this country likely be classified?
questions.solution:
The country belongs to the late expanding stage of the demographic cycle. It is also called the third stage of the demographic cycle.

In the third stage of the demographic cycle, the population continues to grow because the number of births exceeds the number of deaths. Here the death rate keeps declining and the birth rate has a tendency to fall. India is an example of a country in this stage of the demographic cycle.

Other options:

Option A: Declining or the fifth stage of the demographic cycle involves a decline in population because the birth rate is lower than the death rate. Germany is an example of this stage of the demographic cycle.

Option B: Early expanding or the second stage of the demographic cycle involves countries that have a death rate that begins to decline and a birth rate that remains unchanged. This includes many countries in Africa.

Option D: Low-stationary or fourth stage of the demographic cycle involves countries with a stationary population owing to a low birth and death rate. An example of this would be Austria between the years 1980 and 1985.

      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding

    • Stage 3 : Late expanding

      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text:
A young man presents to the ER with complaints of sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of passing loose stools. He gives a history of having food from a nearby bakery three hours ago. What is the mechanism of action of the organism most likely implicated here?

cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient is most likely suffering from gastroenteritis caused by Staphylococcus aureus which acts via preformed Type A enterotoxin.

Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea 2-6 hrs after the consumption of contaminated food. The common sources of infection are foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea. 

Gastroenteritis is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which Type  A toxin is responsible for most cases.

Other options:

Option A: The cholera enterotoxin of Vibrio cholerae binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. It then causes the accumulation of cAMP. A clinical vignette of sudden onset colorless rice watery, stools having an inoffensive sweetish odor is indicative of cholera.

Option B: The enterotoxin of Bacillus cereus involves stimulation of the cAMP system. It may also cause food poisoning independent of the cAMP system. Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or Chinese street food is suggestive of B. cereus. 

Option C: Shiga toxin acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. Shigella dysenteriae causes acute onset of symptoms(fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The microscopic image shows typical brush-like conidiophores seen in Penicillium species.

Microscopic appearance of Penicillium spp.:

  • The hyphae are hyaline and septate.
  • They produce characteristic brush-like conidiophores.
  •  The conidiophore is the stalk-like structure, which bears structures known as metulae from which flask-shaped phialides produce chains of asexual spores known as conidia.

Other options:

Option A: Aspergillus spp. has conidiophores with swollen rounded ends (vesicles) that bear the sterigmata, from which the conidia arise.

Option B: Fusarium spp. on lactophenol cotton blue stain shows small septate hyphae and produces phialides, which give rise to single-celled microconidia or large multi-cell sickle or fusiform-shaped macroconidia, as shown in the image below.

Option D: Scopulariopsis spp. causes onychomycosis, pulmonary infection, fungus ball, and invasive fungal disease in immunocompromised hosts. Microscopically, conidia are large, spherical, lemon-shaped, arranged in chains.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with complaints of diplopia, and progressive headache. Examination of extraocular movements revealed the findings as shown in the image, when the patient attempted to look right. Which cranial nerve lesion is likely responsible for this clinical manifestation, and which eye is affected?

choices.text: Lesion involving left abducens nerve, affecting the left eye
Lesion involving left oculomotor nerve, affecting the left eye
Lesion involving right abducens nerve, affecting the right eye
Lesion involving right oculomotor nerve, affecting the right eye

questions.solution:
The clinical finding shown in the image is suggestive of lateral rectus palsy of the right eye, which occurs due to the lesion involving right abducens nerve. 

The Abducens nerve arises from the brainstem between the pons and medulla oblongata. It enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure and innervates the lateral rectus muscle through its medial (ocular surface).

Determining the palsy:

The abduction and adduction of the eye are caused by the action of the lateral rectus and medial rectus muscles respectively.

The lateral rectus is innervated by the abducens nerve (VI) while the medial rectus is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (III).

Horizontal conjugate movements occur when both eyes move horizontally to look right or left.

  • In the right gaze: The right eye abducts and the left eye adducts.
  • In the left gaze: The right eye adducts and the left eye abducts.

In the image, when the patient attempted to look right, the left eye was adducted normally, while the right eye failed to abduct. This is suggestive of right lateral rectus palsy due to the lesion involving the right abducens nerve.

Note: If the same finding as shown in the image is seen when the patient is looking straight (neutral gaze), then the affected eye is the left eye. In such case, due to left lateral rectus palsy, the action of left medial rectus is unopposed causing adduction of the left eye.

questions.text: A young patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. A provisional diagnosis of hemisection of the spinal cord was made. Which of the following findings will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Contralateral weakness and spasticity of muscle groups.
Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hemisection of the spinal cord following a road traffic accident is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome. A patient with Brown Sequard syndrome will have an ipsilateral loss of vibration sense.

Brown-sequard syndrome is caused due to hemisection of the spinal cord. It can be caused by fracture dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumor. The clinical features are:

questions.text: A child presents with fever for the past 5 days along with rash and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. On examination, the following finding was noted in the soft palate of the child. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever with rash, suboccipital lymphadenopathy, and the image showing Forchheimer's spots (tiny rose-colored lesions on the soft palate) point to the diagnosis of rubella. 

Rubella, also known as German measles is caused by the rubella virus, an enveloped RNA virus belonging to the family Togaviridae. 

The period of infectivity is usually a week before and a week after the onset of the rash appears and the incubation period is around 2-3 weeks. The child presents with low-grade fever, centrifugal macular rash, and prominent lymphadenopathy (suboccipital, postauricular, and anterior cervical lymph nodes). Forchheimer spots may be present.

Other options:

Option B: The measles virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. This follows the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Treatment is supportive. The most common complication of measles is acute otitis media.

Option C: Varicella presents with fever, malaise, and anorexia, followed by a pruritic maculopapular rash, which forms vesicles with a characteristic cropping distribution (simultaneous presence of lesions in various stages of evolution).

Option D: Mumps is caused by a virus belonging to Paramyxoviridae and the genus Rubulavirus. It is an acute self-limited infection characterized by fever, bilateral or unilateral parotid swelling and tenderness, and the frequent occurrence of meningoencephalitis and orchitis.

questions.text: Therapeutic Hypothermia is indicated in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic Hypothermia is indicated in the treatment of Hypoxic Ischaemic Encephalopathy (HIE)

HIE is a form of brain injury that occurs due to inadequate blood flow to the infant’s brain occurring as a result of a hypoxic-ischemic event during the prenatal, intrapartum, or postnatal period. This causes the accumulation of toxic metabolites and depletion of intra-cellular energy that further leads to neuronal injury and death.

Therapeutic Hypothermia involves systemic cooling to achieve a core temperature of 33.5°C within the first 6 hours after birth, for a period of 72 hours. This causes a reduction in the rate of production of toxic compounds and reduces seizure activity, thereby favoring cerebro-protection, especially in HIE due to intrapartum insult. It has been shown to reduce mortality and neuro-development impairment. In adults, therapeutic hypothermia also has a role in the treatment of cardiac arrest to prevent global cerebral ischemia.

The clinical grading is based on Sarnat & Sarnat Staging and HIE is described in three stages as shown below.

Outcome Good Variable Death, severe deficits    

Infants at >36 weeks of gestation with one out of the following four criteria, and in Sarnat Stage 2 or 3 encephalopathies, may be started on therapeutic hypothermia

  • APGAR scores <5 at 10 minutes.
  • Positive pressure ventilation is required at ten minutes
  • Umbilical cord pH or any arterial pH <7, within 1 hour of life
  • Base deficit of more than 16 mmol/L in cord blood or arterial blood within 1 hour of life

Other Options:

Option B: Febrile seizures are managed with anticonvulsants like lorazepam and midazolam. Antipyretics may be used to decrease the child's discomfort but do not treat seizures.

Option C: Malignant Hyperthermia is an anesthetic complication and is managed using IV Dantrolene Sodium in sterile water. The use of ice packs for lowering the body temperature is indicated but only up to normal body temperature, and not to induce hypothermia.

Option D: Neonatal hyperthermia may occur when an infant is exposed to high temperatures (radiant warmer, phototherapy) for prolonged periods. It is managed by removing the infant from the source of heat, followed by cooling in a bath to the normal body temperature. Hypothermia or cooling devices are not indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is the characteristic toxic feature associated with the poison shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows aconite follicles and seeds. The characteristic finding of aconite toxicity is numbness and tingling.

Facts about aconite poisoning

  • Also known as monk's hood or wolf's bane
  • The roots are the most poisonous part of the plant, and are mistaken for horseradish root.
  • Toxic principle : Aconitine
  • Toxicity of aconitine and related alkaloids are due to their actions on the voltage-sensitive sodium channels of the cell membranes of excitable tissues. Aconitine first stimulates and then paralyzes the peripheral terminations of sensory and secretory nerves, CNS, and nerves of the myocardium, skeletal and smooth muscles.
  • Patients present mainly with a combination of gastrointestinal, cardiovascular and neurological features.
  • Numbness and tingling are characteristic features
  • Fatal period : 2-6 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following transport mechanisms is given below?
questions.solution:
The image showing sodium influx and calcium efflux is an example of secondary active counter transport.

Secondary active counter transport - In this form of transport, two or more substances are transported together across the membrane with the help of a carrier molecule. In counter-transport, sodium ions diffuse to the interior of the cell because of the large concentration gradient. Here, the sodium ions bind to the carrier protein on the exterior, and the substance to be counter-transported (calcium in this case) binds to the interior of the carrier protein. Once both are bound, a conformational change occurs, and energy released by the action of the sodium ion moving to the interior causes the other sub- stance to move to the exterior. The examples include:

  • Na+ Ca+ exchanger
  • Na+ H+ exchanger
  • H+ K+ exchanger

Other options:

Option A: Primary active transport - It is a form of cellular transport requiring energy in the form of hydrolysis of ATP to ship and transfer molecules against gradient differences. The important examples of primary active transport include sodium-potassium ATPase, proton pump, and calcium ATPase.

Option B: Secondary active co-transport: Here, the mechanism is similar, but both molecules are transported in the same direction (for example - towards the interior of the cell). One of the examples is SGLT (sodium-glucose co-transporter). Sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT)-1 transports molecules via secondary active transport where two or more molecules are transported together across the membrane with the help of a carrier molecule. As sodium diffuses down its electrochemical gradient, the energy released is used to drive glucose against the gradient. Other example include Na+ K+ 2Cl- co-transporter.

Option D: Facilitated diffusion - Transporting the molecule from one side of the cell membrane to the other is done with the help of transport proteins called carriers. Molecules move from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration. No energy input is required when carrier proteins move substances in the direction of their gradients. Glucose(GLUT) transport by the glucose transporter is an example, which moves glucose down its concentration gradient from the ECF to the cytoplasm of the cell.

questions.text: What will be the amount of blood flow in vessel A compared to vessel B, given that both the vessels have the  same pressure and follow a linear flow pattern.
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the amount of blood flow in vessel A is 8 times greater than vessel B. 

In the given scenario, according to Poiseuille’s law, which describes the relationship between fluid flow, the radius of the vessel, and its length, several changes affect the flow:

  • Doubling the radius: Poiseuille’s law states that flow is proportional to the fourth power of the radius. So, if the radius is doubled, the flow increases by a factor of 2^4 = 16. This means that the wider vessel allows significantly more flow.
  • Doubling the length: Poiseuille’s law also states that flow is inversely proportional to the length of the vessel. If the length is doubled, the flow is reduced by half.

Combining these effects, the flow increases by a factor of 16 due to the radius but is reduced by half due to the increased length. Therefore, the net increase in flow is 16/ 2 = 8. Hence, the correct answer is 8, as the flow is eight times greater than before.

questions.text: A body of a 30-year-old man is retrieved from the local river and subjected to autopsy. His family accuses his friend of murdering him by pushing him into the river after making him unconscious by hitting his head with a wooden stick. Which autopsy finding will favor the family's accusation?
questions.solution:
The finding of edema aquosum in the autopsy will favor the family's accusation.

Edema aquosum occurs when the victim is alive but unconscious at the time of the drowning. This is mere flooding of the lungs with the water without the formation of froth as respiratory efforts are absent.

Autopsy findings in drowning include, froth in the air passages, waterlogging of the lung, emphysema aquosum, paltauf’s spots, hemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone.

Other options :

Option B: Hydrostatic lung, is seen in postmortem drowning. When a dead body is thrown into the water, water passes into the lungs due to hydrostatic pressure. 

Option C: Emphysema aquosum - This is seen in cases when the victim is alive and conscious. Overinflation of the lungs in drowning is known as emphysema aquosum. It is one of the most valuable positive signs of drowning. The edema fluid in the bronchi blocks the passive collapse that normally occurs at death. Hence, the lungs are held in the inspiratory position. The impression of the ribs on this overinflated lung leaves visible and palpable grooves on the lateral surface. 

Option D: Diatom test- Diatoms are microscopic algae. Their presence in the organs, particularly in the bone marrow, is suggestive of antemortem drowning. In postmortem drowning, diatoms do not spread to distant organs because of absence of circulation and are limited to the lungs.
